Author: ['ET Online']
Title: ['OMCs gain on reports of hike in diesel price; BPCL hits 52-week high']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: State-run oil marketing companies (OMCS) surged over 5 per cent in early trade on Friday on reports that the oil ministry proposes to increase fuel prices, particularly diesel, by less than arupeeper month."The ministry has also proposed to reduce one-third subsidy on kerosene by 2014-15 and on cooking gas by a quarter this year, government officials said," ET reported.BPCLsurged over 2 per cent to hit its 52-week high of Rs 379.70 today. At 12:00 pm, BPCL was trading 2.8 per cent higher at Rs 376.75.HPCLwas trading 4.5 per cent higher at Rs 310.75. It has hit a low of Rs 296.55 and a high of Rs 312.25 in trade today.ONGCwas up 2.2 to Rs 286.05 andOil Indiamoved 3.6 per cent higher to Rs 488.The move is expected to reduce the government\'s subsidy burden substantially on diesel, kerosene and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), officials said.Oil Marketing Companies are having a dream run backed by the expectations of the proposed norms raised by theOil ministerthat is to hike diesel prices in a phased manner and eventually to deregulate the diesel prices to align with the market rates, experts say."If the proposed criterion gets implemented will act as a boon for the OMCs(Viz; IOC,BPCL,HPCL) as they are the ones inherently being the victim of under recoveries by selling their products at subsidized rates," says Soumyadip Raha, Executive Research-Oil & Gas atMicrosec Capital Ltd."Moreover this move will bring the more clarity on the OMCs financials as well as improve the overall health of the company," added Raha.However, Raha is of the view that possible logjam could be a hindrance in implementations of these reforms."Rise in international crude oil prices coupled with Rupee depreciation against the USD resulted in higher under-recoveries for oil marketing companies (OMCs) on account of selling diesel, kerosene and domestic LPG at subsidized rates,"Angel Brokingsaid in a report.According to the oil ministry\'s recent data, state oil firms are losing Rs 9 a litre on diesel, Rs 30.60 on kerosene and Rs 490 per cylinder on cooking gas.The estimated fuel subsidy for 2012-13 is about Rs 166,000 crore, out of which the finance ministry has sanctioned Rs 30,000 crore and released the first installment of Rs 10,000 crore to state oil marketing firms this week.During the first half of December 2012, OMCs continued to lose Rs 411cr per day. OMCs lost Rs 9.3/liter, Rs 30.1/liter and Rs 521/cylinder on diesel, kerosene and domestic LPG, respectively."The oil ministry is seeking more than Rs 100,000 crore from the finance ministry to compensate the three oil firms for selling fuel below market rates in the current fiscal year," added the ET report.State-run upstream companies such as ONGC and Oil India are expected to shoulder about Rs 55,000-crore subsidy burden this year. The marketing firms would absorb the balance, officials said.']

Author: ['ET Online']
Title: ['Hot stock: Barclays see over 20% upside in BPCL']
Content: ['MUMBAI:BarclaysEquity Research has maintained its overweight rating onBPCLwith a target price of Rs 455, an upside of over 20 per cent from its current market price.According to the brokerage, despite the near-term earnings uncertainly, BPCL\'s upstream portfolio spanning 26 assets in seven countries has proved to be a game changer with multiple oil and gas discoveries since 2008."We expect news flow to remain constructive over 2013-14, and see greater appreciation of value, as the Mozambique project nears final investment decision and clarity emerges on resources and monetisation in Brazil," the report said.The company\'s upstream assets will require Rs75-80 billion in capex over the next five years. Though the balance sheet appears stretched, the company investment outlay is manageable, the brokerage says."The balance sheet is stretched due to high working capital debt, but the investment outlay is manageable with comfortable access to debt and project finance.Annual operating cash flow of Rs40bn, oil bonds and government receivables of Rs 150 billion, and treasury stock of Rs 25 billion at current market prices will also help," it added.However, high crude prices will keep retail fuel under-recoveries in India elevated and doesn\'t bode well for the company.According to the report, while policy interventions have helped every year, an election heavy 2013 may prevent sweeping changes and may hurt the company\'s near-term earnings. Besides, a surplus global refining scenario with 5mbpd of additions over 2012-14 adds to problems."We value BPCL\'s core business at 0.65x P/B given uncertainties about earnings and the upstream portfolio at Rs172/share. Of this the Mozambique asset is Rs120/share - a 35-40 per cent discount to the values implied by the M&A; bids for Cove Energy in 2012. A spike in crude prices is the key near-term risk, but lower LNG contract prices, timeline delays, cost over-runs and any potential adverse host country action in Mozambique are longer-term risks," the report added.']

Author: ['ET Online']
Title: ['OMCs extend gains on proposal to hike diesel prices; BPCL hits 52-week high']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: State-runoil marketing companies(OMCs) extended their rally on Monday on theoil ministry\'s proposal to increase fuel prices, particularlydiesel, by less than arupeeper month.Diesel, kerosene and cooking gas LPG prices may be hiked soon as the government is considering the Vijay Kelkar Committee recommendations on the cutting fiscal deficit.BPCLsurged over 3 per cent to hit its 52-week high of Rs 387.80 today. At 11:30 am, BPCL was trading 3.07 per cent higher at Rs 385.50.HPCLwas trading 3.8 per cent higher at Rs 325.95. It has hit a low of Rs 315 and a high of Rs 327.45 in trade today.ONGCwas up 1.3 to Rs 288.55 andOil Indiamoved 0.5 per cent higher to Rs 48.3.75Oil marketing companies are having a dream run backed by the expectations thatdiesel priceswill be hiked in a phased manner and will eventually be deregulated to align with the market rates, experts say."The Kelkar Committee, which was appointed by theFinance Ministryto suggest a roadmap for fiscal consolidation, has suggested an immediate hike in fuel prices and complete deregulation of diesel prices by the start of fiscal 2014-15. It has also suggested raising kerosene and LPG rates," PTI reported."Fair trade regulator Competition Commission said it will seek details from oil marketing companies on their petrol pricing mechanism to probe the alleged cartelisation among them in fixing the fuel price," said the report.']

Author: ['ET Now']
Title: ['Phased hike may wipe out under-recoveries in one year: RK Singh, BPCL']
Content: ['In an interview withET Now, RK Singh, CMD,BPCL, shares his views on the proposeddiesel price hikeand its impact on the sector. Excerpts:ET Now: The oil ministry on Friday clearly indicated that a fuel price hike is being considered. Have you heard anything from the ministry on that?RK Singh:If a minister has made a statement, I cannot add or delete anything from there, but all I know is that there is some proposal only. This is a proposal stage. I am not party to such a decision. I am only hearing from the newspapers and from you people. Now that you have heard from the minister, that must be true.ET Now: So assuming a price hike does not or rather does come about, what has been talked about in terms ofrupeeper month on diesel, what is going to be the impact of it?RK Singh:If that indeed gets done, I am not sure because I told you this is a proposal I have heard about. And as you said the minister has made such a statement. I take it that it must be true. If that does happen and if the crude prices remain at this level and rupee-dollar exchange rate also does not fluctuate much, it remains at the same rate as it is today, then the increase of Re 1 per month will wipe out the entire under-recovery in a year or so.That will certainly increase the cash position of the oil companies because right now we are compensated by the government and money comes late and in the interim period we have to borrow heavily from the banks at very high interest rates. All these problems will be resolved to a large extent because cash positions of oil companies will improve, thereby the borrowing will come down and we will be able to mobilise working capital through own sources.ET Now: But does it look realistic -- Re 1 per month on diesel -- given the kind of political compulsions we have?RK Singh:To me it does not look unrealistic at all. If any government or anybody increases the price by Rs 10 in one go, that will be a chaotic situation and people will feel the shock, but if you do it in a phased manner, people will get adjusted to it and it will not be a sudden shock to the economy. So it is a good move. I entirely agree with that if it happens and it will be good for theeconomy, good for the country, and good for the oil companies.ET Now: There are also reports that probably the government will reform the formula according to whichunder-recoveriesare being calculated, this also may lead to low under recoveries. What are your thoughts if this proposal is to be considered?RK Singh:I am not aware of any such proposal that the formula calculating the under-recovery is being reviewed or changed, but currently marketing companies are paying a price to the refineries what we call is refinery gate price and on that they are adding their normal marketing margins and the cost, cost of distribution and that is how we determine the sales price. And we are selling below the actual price. That is under-recovery that we talk about. I do not know where the mistake is. If there are some changes taking place in the refinery gate price formula that is a different thing. Actually it is a trade parity that we are paying to the refining companies. If there is any such change, the government or whoever is going to make the change will have to examine the refinery profitability as well because we have to make heavy investment in the refinery sector and we have to invest in the marketing infrastructure. So I do not think money can be mobilised if we tinker with the refinery gate price.']

Author: ['PTI']
Title: ['HPCL, BPCL shares rally on hopes of fuel price hike']
Content: ['MUMBAI: Bucking the overall weak trend, state owned oil companies, includingHPCLandBPCL, today rose by as much as 5 per cent on renewed hopes of fuel price hike soon.Shares of HPCL gained 4.79 per cent to close at Rs 328.95 and BPCL rose by 3.28 per cent to Rs 385.30 on theBSE.IOCL ended 0.37 per cent higher at Rs 282.50. Buying was also seen inONGCwhose shares rose by 1.04 per cent.Brokers said the shares gained on reports that diesel, kerosene and cooking gas prices may be hiked soon while the government may separately take up a proposal to raise the cap on supply of subsidised LPG cylinders.TheKelkar Committee, which was appointed byFinance Ministryto suggest a roadmap for fiscal consolidation, had recommended an immediate hike in price of diesel by Rs 4 per litre, of kerosene by Rs 2 a litre and of LPG by Rs 50 per cylinder.Meanwhile, in the stock market the BSE benchmarkSensexended 92.66 points lower at 19,691.42.']

Author: ['ET Online']
Title: ['JPMorgan cautious on R&M space; prefers BPCL']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: Global brokerage firmJPMorganis cautious on therefining and marketing space(R&M;) as implementation of hike in diesel prices remains vague - leading to potential for delays.JPMorgan remains cautious on the R&M; space, and prefersBPCLfor its upstream leverage. However, they think that initial periodic hikes are likely to be a positive sentiment for most OMSc. JPMorgan recommends booking profits inHPCLandIOCL.The oil minister announced that the OMCs are free to hike diesel prices periodically, in \'small\' increments.The moveis a clear positive for OMCs, but political headwinds remain."A move toward market pricing is positive. However, in our view risks to implementation remain, particularly as the periodicity and the quantum of hikes remain unclear," JPMorgan said in a report."While we could see an initial few hikes, opposition to this measure is likely to be high, and as with petrol, we could see this process play out in fits and starts," added the report.JPMorgan is ofthe viewthat a road map to move to market pricing of diesel would act as a sentiment positive, and delivery on the same could see thestocksrerate.BPCL has delivered a more stable refining performance over the past few quarters, aiding earnings. However, the brokerage firm remains cautious on HPCL, and advises investors to book profits on the back of near-term rallies.']

Author: ['ET Online']
Title: ['Diesel price hike likely to benefit BPCL, IOC, HPCL: Moody?s']
Tags: ['ONGC', 'BPCL', 'GAIL', 'CLSA', 'Deutsche Bank', 'Indian Oil Corporation Ltd.', 'Bharat Petroleum Corporation Ltd.']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: Global rating agency Moody\'s in a note on Monday said the government move to authorise the state-run oil marketing companies to hike the fuel price periodically is credit positive forBPCL, HPCL and IOC."The authorisation is credit positive for all three companies because higher diesel prices will reduce the amount of fuel subsidy they need to temporarily absorb until they receive a full or partial payment from the government," said the rating agency note.This partial deregulation aims to reduce government subsidies paid to the firms and lower the companies\' losses on fuel sales. "Although it is unclear how much leeway the companies will get in determining the amount and timing of the diesel price revisions, the authorization marks the first time that they are able to raise prices," Moody\'s said.Following the news, shares of all the three oil & gas companies surged over 10 per cent last week. For the year 2013, BPCL surged over 20 per cent, HPCL managed to clock a return on 28 per cent while IOC rose over 27 per cent compared to a 3 per cent rise in the benchmark index in the same period.The rating agency is of the view that this partial freeing up of diesel prices is a positive step for BPCL and IOC towards recovering the Rs 9.60 per litre loss they incur on the sale of diesel.Moody\'s expects BPCL\'s and IOC\'s credit metrics to improve as diesel prices rise. The subsidy on diesel alone is worth Rs 94,000 crore per year. All three government-owned oil marketing companies share the risk associated with a largely ad-hoc mechanism for subsidy reimbursement.According to the Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas, the under-recoveries to the three oil marketing companies have been rising over the past three years. For the nine months ending 31 December, diesel composed 59 per cent of the companies\' total under-recoveries of Rs 1.25 billion.Last week different brokerage firms came out with their recommendations post the partial-deregulations. We take a look at a few of them:Nomura:The brokerage firm said the rally in state-run oil companies, spurred by the government\'s announcement to allow higher diesel prices, was excessive and the action would not lead to any improvement in the bottom line of these companies.Nomura maintains its \'reduce\' rating onOil and Natural GasCorp andOil India Ltd.Deutsche BankThe global bank expects the decision of the government to ease the process of diesel price revision as it does not have to be referred to the Cabinet for approval. Deutsche Bank also believes that if the diesel price is raised regularly, even if the increase is as small as less than Rs 0.5/litre per month, it will be a positive step to reduce fuel subsidies benefitingONGC, OIL andGAIL.CLSA:The experience with petrol and a busy 2013 political calendar make it doubt any significant follow up in price hike. The oil & gas stocks are euphoric and already building in 3-16 months of price hikes,CLSAsaid in a report.At current rupee and crude assumptions, CLSA expects the under-recoveries to decline to Rs 852 billion. Keeping upstream sharing at 40 per cent, it expects 62/73 per cent upgrade in EPS of ONGC (Rs 20) and OIL (Rs 45).The brokerage firm finds IOC (GRM of $5.2/bbl) and HPCL (GRM of $4.8/bbl) near peer multiples and sees upsides capped even in this blue sky case. CLSA continues to prefer BPCL in the R&M; space due to its upstream footprint.JPMorganGlobal brokerage firm, JPMorgan is cautious on the refining and marketing space (R&M;) as implementation of hike in diesel prices remains vague - leading to potential for delays.JPMorgan remains cautious on the R&M; space and prefers BPCL for its upstream leverage. However, they think that initial periodic hikes are likely to be a sentiment positive for most OMSc. JPMorgan recommends booking profits in HPCL and IOCL.']

Author: ['ByRamkrishna Kashelkar, ET Bureau']
Title: ['Government aid helps IndianOil, BPCL and HPCL post profits for Q3']
Content: ["Three state-ownedoil marketing companies(OMCs) have been able to post profits for the December '12 quarter thanks to the government agreeing to make good most of their losses. But the companies remain in losses in the 9 months to the December quarter as the government's portion of compensation is yet to be received. Nevertheless, they seem to have been fully compensated for the Oct-Dec '12 quarter.The three OMCs -IndianOil,BPCLandHPCL- received adequate compensation from the government and upstream companies to cover their losses, unlike the inadequate compensation of the earlier two quarters.Industry leader IndianOil, which had lost a net Rs 13,635 crore in the April-September 2012 period, reported a drop in net under-recovery at Rs 13,227 crore for the 9-month period (April-December 2012). Similarly, the second biggest player BPCL reported a drop in net under-recovery to Rs 5,917 crore for April-December 2012 from Rs 6,133 crore of the initial six months.In spite of this improvement in the 3-month period ending December '12, the companies remain in the red for the financial year so far, as losses from earlier period are yet to be compensated.Over the past few years, the government has adopted the approach of compensating the OMCs in the March ending quarter of the fiscal to ensure they don't post losses on an annual basis. As a result, the March '13 quarter will be an important one for the industry.IndianOil was the only company to post a jump in profits for the December '12 quarter with BPCL and HPCL witnessing sharp reduction on a y-o-y basis. However, this was mainly due toIOCwriting off Rs 6,168 crore towards entry-tax arrears under litigation in Uttar Pradesh.On the other hand, what the companies have received for the October-December 2012 quarter is just an assurance letter from the government towards the compensation and not the actual cash.The cash would be paid only afterParliamentapprovessupplementary budget expenditure. This means the ground reality for these companies doesn't change much as the problems related to working capital crunch, high debt and interest burden would continue."]

Author: ['ET Online']
Title: ['HPCL, BPCL, IOC rally post diesel price hike']
Content: ['MUMBAI: Shares of oil marketing companies were in limelight in early trade after diesel prices were hiked by 45 paise on Friday.At 09:30 a.m.;BPCLrallied 2.57 per cent,HPCLgained 2.38 per cent,IOCmoved 1.74 per cent, ONGC was up 3.04 per cent and GAIL advanced 1.31 per cent.This is the third time thatOMCshave hiked diesel prices after the government allowed them to increase diesel prices marginally every month to reduce under-recoveries."This is the third hike since January 17, when the cabinet had decided to empower the OMCs to increase the price of diesel by small proportion every month," Angel Broking said in a note.Earlier last week, OMCs had reduced the price of petrol by Rs 2 and had kept diesel prices unchanged."This move is positive for upstream companies under our coverage (ONGC and Gail) as it will help them reduce the subsidy burden. However, we maintain our under recovery estimates and would revise them post 4QFY2013 results," said the note."Important to highlight is the fact that the price increases are finally happening and if it continues to go on like this in spite of the political wicket being slightly weak for the government, it gives us confidence that somewhere things could probably start working out in favour of reforms rather than vacillating back to populism," said Prakash Diwan, Chief Portfolio Strategist, Prakash Diwan\'s Wealth Circle in an interview with ET Now.According to IOC, even after the hike, oil firms are losing Rs 8.19 per litre. They are losing Rs. 33.43 per litre on sale of kerosene through the PDS system and Rs. 439 on LPG cylinder.The under recoveries for the OMCs for FY13 are likely to be Rs 1,63,000 crore on diesel, LPG and kerosene sale. Revenue loss for IOC alone is estimated at Rs. 86,400 crore.']

Author: ['PTI']
Title: ['BPCL seeks bids from suppliers for LNG import']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: State-ownedBharat PetroleumCorp Ltd (BPCL) has sought bids fromliquefied natural gas(LNG) suppliers for short-term import of the fuel to meet domestic demand.BPCL plans to import LNG from thespot marketto meet the deficit arising from fall in output from domestic natural gas fields. It wants to import LNG at Dahej terminal in Gujarat or at Kochi in Kerala.The company has called for Expression of Interest by May 2 for signing a Master Sales and Purchase Agreement with LNG suppliers."BPCL\'s preferred mode of purchase of the spot cargoes would be through short notice tenders, which would be invited from panel of suppliers who have signedMSPAwith BPCL," it said in the tender document. "BPCL may enter in to MSPA for a minimum period of five years."LNG is natural gas that has been cooled to become liquid for ease of shipping. At the import site, it is reconverted into gas, a process called regassification.The eligibility criteria includes the applicant having a minimum annual turnover of USD 50 million and a networth of USD 25 million.Bids have been sought from producers/suppliers of LNG from any of the existing LNG supply plants or from those who have a valid Sales and Purchase Agreement with an entity having an LNG liquefication project without any delivery and destination restrictions.Suppliers who have traded at least 2 cargoes of capacity 75000 cubic meter each as spot cargoes or long term/short term of LNG during last one year or has an agreement with any existing LNG producer to market LNG on their behalf in India can also apply, the tender documents said.It is also open to buying LNG from a firm which owns or operates LNG import terminal in India.BPCL is equal promoter in Petronet LNG Ltd, which operates a 10 million tons a year import and regassification facility at Dahej in Gujarat and is building a 5 million tons terminal at Kochi in Kerala this year.The country is facing a fuel scarcity as gas production from the Reliance Industries\' eastern offshore KG-D6 fields dropped to about 17 million standard cubic meters per day this month from 63-64 mmscmd it had hit in March 2010.']

Author: ['PTI']
Title: ['CCI rejects market abuse charges against BPCL']
Tags: ['Bharat Petroleum Corp Ltd', 'CCI', 'BPCL', 'Bharat Petroleum', 'Competition Commission of India']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: Fair trade regulatorCCIhas dismissed complaints ofBharat Petroleum Corp Ltd(BPCL) abusing its market dominance in transportation of LPG cylinders from bottling plants to distributors across the country.Competition Commission of India(CCI) has said "there does not exist a prima facie case" for directing its investigation arm, Director General, to probe the matter against BPCL.Certain LPG cylinder transporters in Kerala and Tamil Nadu had alleged BPCL of introducing a system of reservation of routes to the LPG distributors, among other things.It was alleged BPCL abused its dominant market position by imposing unfair and discriminatory conditions for services and indulged in practices resulting in denial of market access to the complainants.Further, it had been alleged that BPCL reserved 50 per cent of the routes for the distributors and entered into exclusive distribution agreement with them.However, CCI in its order dated April 10 has said BPCL did not "appear to be a dominant procurer of the services of trucks for transportation of goods" as there were enough players for hiring such services in the country.Regarding allegations that BPCL introduced changes in the existing practice of delivery of LPG cylinders, CCI said: "Based on hiring transport services selected through a tender, to a new model which is partly based on open tender and partly based on agreement with its distributors, (this) cannot be inferred to be anti-competitive or denial of market access".The fair trade regulator said "prima facie it does not appear to be a case of tie-in arrangement, exclusive supply agreement or exclusive distribution agreement, between BPCL and its distributors"."So far as conditions of tender are concerned, BPCL has business liberty for any changes in the tender for its own interests and can procure services from service providers other than the informant," CCI said."Besides, the presence of other buyers of the services of the informant indicates that there is no appreciable adverse effect on competition as such," it added.']

Author: ['PTI']
Title: ['Videocon, BPCL strike natural gas in Mozambique block']
Tags: ['Videocon Industries', 'Bharat Petroleum Corp Ltd', 'BPCL', 'Eni', 'Anadarko Petroleum', 'Mitsui & Co', 'Videocon Hydrocarbon Holdings']
Subtitle: ['Videocon Industries and Bharat Petroleum Corp Ltd (BPCL) have reported a fourth huge natural gas discovery in an offshore Mozambique block']
Content: ['NEW DELHI:VideoconIndustries andBharatPetroleum Corp Ltd (BPCL) have reported a fourth huge natural gas discovery in an offshore Mozambique block, where they hold 10 per cent stake each.Videocon Hydrocarbon Holdings, a wholly owned subsidiary ofVideocon Industries, and Bharat PetroResources Ltd, a unit of BPCL, said a new discovery has made in the offshore Area 1 of the Rovuma basin, the two firms said in almost identical but separate statements."The Orca-1 discovery well encountered approximately 190 net feet (58 meters) of natural gas pay in a Paleocene fan system," they said.US energy firmAnadarko PetroleumCorp is the operator with 36.5 per cent stake in Mozambique\'s offshore Area 1, which may hold as much as 70 Trillion cubic feet of gas resources.Videocon and BPCL hold 10 per cent stake each in the block where Japan\'s Mitsui & Co Ltd is the second-biggest stakeholder with a 20 per cent interest.Thai state oil company PTT Exploration and Production PCL has an 8.5 per cent interest and Mozambique\'s state-owned ENH 15 per cent."The Orca-1 exploration well was drilled to a total depth of approximately 16,391 feet, in water depths of 3,481 feet," the statements said.Two major natural gas discoveries have so far been made in Offshore Area 1 of Mozambique\'s Rovuma Basin. The Prosperidade complex is estimated to hold between 17 and 30-plus Tcf of recoverable natural gas while separate and distinct Golfinho/Atum complex is estimated to hold 15-35 Tcf of recoverable natural gas resources.Evaluation of a third discovery on the block, Tubarao, is ongoing with an appraisal well that is expected to be drilled this year.The gas found in Offshore Area 1 is to be turned into liquefied natural gas (LNG) and shipped to markets like India. The plant in the Cabo Delgado province in northern Mozambique, is scheduled to start operating in 2018 with a capacity of 20 million tonnes of LNG per year.The capacity will be split evenly between operators of Offshore Area-1 and Italian giantEni, which is developing gas found in the neighbouring Offshore Area 4.']

Author: ['ET Bureau']
Title: ['Brokers? call: BPCL, HCL Tech and TCS']
Content: ['BPCLto Touch Rs 489: MacquarieMacquarie Equities Researchhas maintained its \'Outperform\' rating on Bharat Petroleum with a target price of Rs 489. It said in the past two years, BPCL has created huge value from overseas upstream ventures, including Mozambique, which now accounts for 2/5ths of BPCL\'s total value."The flow rate from discovery well MD-3 is significant at around 800 boe pd, 90% of this is oil. Also the hydrocarbon bearing interval is a significant 75 metres. We estimate that this exploratory well alone would add Rs 1.6 billion pa to BPCL turnover.While too early to gauge, BPCL\'s profits could be enhanced by Rs 0.6 billion pa or 4 % just from this one well given that it is mainly sweet light onland crude oil," it said in a note, adding that BPCL has now been one of the best-performingstocksfor more than a decade.Prospects of diesel de-control following recent collapse in global crude oil prices, is yet another potential multi-bagger trigger.Morgan Overweight on HCLMorgan Stanleyhas maintained its \'Overweight\' rating on HCL Technologies. It said HCL Tech delivered overall revenues, EBIT and net profit ahead of their and Street expectations.Strong execution and tight cost control has helped HCL Tech sustain its margins in March \'13 quarter. The stock currently trades at 15x FY13 and 13xFY14e EPS on MS estimates.Resurgence in revenue growth along with stable margins in FY14e should be required to drive the stock higher from current levels. HCL Tech reported revenues of $1,191 million (+3.2% qoq, +13.6% yoy). Revenues slowed down qoq, however, continued to accelerate on yoy basis.On constant currency terms, revenues grew +3.8% qoq and +15.2% yoy. EBIT margins surprised positively and remained at 19.5% (+2bps qoq, +425bps yoy). Net income of Rs 10.2 billion (+8% qoq, +75% yoy) was helped by higher than expected other income.HCL Tech continues to deliver in-line revenue growth. Over the last 12 months, strong 400bps improvement in EBIT margins has helped stock performance. We remain comfortable with our F14e EPS forecasts, the brokerage house said in a note.GoldmanStays Neutral on TCSGoldman Sachshas maintained its \'Neutral\' rating on TCS with a target price of Rs 1,520 as it believes that sector leading revenue growth and cash returns are already priced in.TCS is trading at 17.9X FY14E P/E, at a 21% premium toInfosysdue to its better revenue and EPS growth outlook. TCS posted 4QFY13 inline revenues ofRs 164.3 billion (+2.2% qoq), EBIT of Rs 43.6 billion and net income of Rs 36 billion. It said dollar revenue growth at 3.2% qoq was broad-based across verticals helped byIndia business(+19.4% qoq).The management reiterated that FY14 would be a better year for them vs. FY13.BFSI (+4.3% qoq) turned out to be the strongest vertical, contributing 60% of incremental revenues in the quarter vs. revenue share of 43.5%,enterprise services (+6.8% qoq) and infra services (+6.6% qoq) were the strongest service areas, similar to the trend in HCL too.']

Author: ['ET Now']
Title: ['No under recovery on petrol right now: RK Singh, BPCL']
Subtitle: ['The under-recovery on diesel could be in the range of Rs 4 to Rs 5 as against Rs 11-12 earlier, says RK Singh, CMD, BPCL.']
Content: ["In an interview with ET Now, RK Singh, CMD, BPCL, shares his business outlook and talks about their new discovery. Excerpts:ET Now: First a word on the new discovery which you have announced two-three days ago, the offshore area of the Rovuma Basin.RK Singh: As you know, we have drilled a number of wells there earlier and there have been discoveries. The reserve estimated is in the range of 35 tcf to 65 tcf. Some more wells in the neighbouring areas were to be drilled, which has been done now and there has been a fresh discovery in one of the wells called Orca. That is what we have announced, but we need to drill two more appraisal wells to actually estimate the amount of gas that would be available in addition to what we have announced already.ET Now: So with this new discovery in place, how does the total potential of the block look like?RK Singh: As I told you, the quantity estimated so far and announced by the operator is in the range of 35 to 65 tcf, but other than that, this is a fresh discovery which will add to the number already announced by us. But how much is yet to be assessed because we need to drill two more appraisal wells in the same vicinity. After that only we should be able to tell you as to how much additionality will be there.ET Now: So what is the development plan of the main operator? Are there chances of more recoveries from the Rovuma Basin?RK Singh: Yes, indeed. Some more wells are yet to be drilled. So my own guess is (the operator has not announced, but I am just guessing the figure being part of the consortium) that it can go in excess of 100 tcf. The final reserve that we are talking about it can go up to 100 or in excess of 100 tcf. The development plan is that initially we are all planning to put up two trains of LNG for liquefaction of the gas that is available and the total development expenditure estimated including that of the terminal and liquefaction plant is estimated to be about $20 billion. Our share will be of course $2 billion. So the first two trains for the liquefaction transportation will be ready by 2017-2018.ET Now: So with crude oil prices coming down, how much are you benefiting in terms of low under recoveries?RK Singh: Losses have indeed come down. When you talk about them, basically there is under recovery on diesel which used to be Rs 10-12 with the latest reduction in crude price as also the product price. I have not worked out the exact number because we do it every fortnightly, but as indications are it could be around Rs 4 to Rs 5 per litre. If the prices continue to slide, as they are today or if they remain at today's level, the under-recovery on diesel could be in the range of Rs 4 to Rs 5 as against Rs 11-12 earlier. Of course there is no under recovery on petrol and likewise the prices of kerosene and LPG have also come down, but we would let you know the exact reduction maybe after the fortnight or by the end of this month."]

Author: ['ET Bureau']
Title: ["RIL, BPCL reject Parliamentary Panel's allegations of loss in hedging crude oil purchases"]
Subtitle: ['Oil firms resort to hedging to shield themselves from highly volatile international crude oil market.']
Content: ['NEW DELHI:Reliance Industries(RIL) and theBharat Petroleum(BPCL) have rebuted theparliamentary committeereport quoting the chairman of Bharat Petroleum Corp as saying that Reliance Industries had lost money inhedging crude oil purchases. Reacting to the report, Bharat Petroleum said that it did not make any specific comment about another company.The standing committee on petroleum and natural gas had asked state refiners about the merits of hedging. The committee\'s report quotes the BPCL chairman as saying: "It can work either way. For example, Reliance lost huge money in hedging, but in our case, we have to take permission from the RBI." Responding to a query from ET, a spokesman for BPCL said: "This is to confirm that BPCL has not made any specific comment on the business practices or activities of any other oil company."Reliance said the allegation was false. "There is no truth in the statement of RIL incurring hedging losses. We have consistently performed better with respect to Singapore complex margins as well as PSU refiners," RIL spokesperson told ET.Oil firms resort to hedging to shield themselves from highly volatile international crude oil market. The committee members wanted to know from state oil firms?Indian Oil Corp (IOC),Hindustan Petroleum Corp(HPCL) and BPCL ? why they shy away from hedging volatility risks when they purchase about 20 per cent of their requirements from thespot market, government officials present in the meeting said.But, state oil firms, which undergo stringent audit byCAG, don\'t want to take the risk of hedging. "We can go up to a certain amount. It\'s a risky affair. So, at times it can work in your favour, but many times it can work against you. If it goes against you, then you are answerable to all kinds of queries," the report quoting Singh said. "When they (private firms) hedge, they lose heavily and nobody questions because they have their own company, but when we lose we will be subjected to all kinds of queries and people will be held accountable. Who will going to answer to all these?," the report quoting Singh said.TheReserve Bank of Indiaallowsdomestic oil refining and marketing companiesto hedge their price risk on crude oil and petroleum products on overseas exchanges and markets to modulate the impact of adverse price fluctuations. Theoil ministrytold the committee that long-term contracts are preferred mode of crude oil purchases, but refiners meet about 20 per cent their crude oil requirements though spot markets.India\'scrude oil importin 2012-13 was worth Rs 782,950 crore, which included about 80 per cent long-term contract and 20 per cent spot purchases, an oil ministry official said.Indiaimports more than 80 per cent of crude oil it processes.']

Author: ['ET Online']
Title: ['HPCL, BPCL tank over 3% on weak rupee']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: Oil marketing companies such asHPCLandBPCLslipped over 3 per cent in trade on Monday asrupeecontinued its downward trajectory against the dollar to hit its new all time low.The rupee hit a fresh record low of 57.80 vs dollar following disappointing data from China and slightly better-than-expected US jobs data. The partially convertible rupee closed at of 57.06 on Friday.HPCL slipped over 3 per cent to hit its 52-week low of Rs 270 in trade today. At 03:00 p.m.; the stock was trading 2.95 per cent lower at Rs 272.90. It hit a low of Rs 270 and a high of Rs 283 in trade today.BPCL was trading 2.5 per cent lower at Rs 366.50. It hit a low of Rs 364.20 and a high of Rs 379.35 in trade today.Indian Oil Corporationwas trading 1.4 per cent lower at Rs 266.05. It hit a low of Rs 265.20 and a high of Rs 274 in trade today.According to analysts, the fall is largely triggered by broad gains in the dollar that is also hitting other emerging currencies such as the Japanese Yen, over worries about a potential end to the US stimulus programme.Most analysts expect dollar index to hit 88 levels by year-end and the outlook for rupee remains bearish with target of Rs 58-60 against the dollar.Weakness in rupee makes it harder tofinanceIndia\'s ballooning current account deficit, which hit a record 6.7 per cent ofgross domestic productin the October-December quarter.India already has such a large current account deficit and a depreciating currency makes imports costlier, which will lead to a rise in theinflationnumber.BofA-ML is of the view that India will have to live with a high current account deficit as long as we live in a world of low growth, curbing exports and high G-3 liquidity which is pumping up the oil import bill."Additionally, the current account deficit has actually expanded as growth has fallen," said a report by BofA-ML.']

Author: ['ET Online']
Title: ['Rupee depreciation negative for IOC, HPCL, BPCL: Moody?s']
Content: ["NEW DELHI: A sharp depreciation in therupeehas negated most of the benefits for theoil marketing companiesfrom the decline in fuel subsidies in view of price reforms which started in September 2012 and from a near 8% retreat in crude oil prices on a USD basis, Moody's Investors service said in a report on Thursday.TheIndian rupee(INR) has depreciated nearly 12 per cent since the beginning of the fiscal year in April 2013 and reached an all-time low of 60.73 against theUS dollaron 26 June 2013.The rupee depreciation is negative for the state-owned oil marketing companies likeIndian Oil Corporation(IOC, Baa3 stable), Bharat Petroleum Corporation Ltd (BPCL, Baa3 stable) andHindustan PetroleumCorporation Ltd, which continue to import about 70-75 per cent of their crude oil needs and rely heavily on foreign currency borrowings, which largely remain unhedged.The rating agency is ofthe viewthat if the Indian currency continues to depreciate and averages 62 against the USD and crude prices remain at elevated levels and average at $108/ barrel for FYE3/2014, subsidies could return to Rs 1.6 trillion, a level similar to FYE3/2013.Moody's expects the country's fuel subsidies to reach Rs 1.3 trillion for FYE3/2014 on account of sharp depreciation in the currency, compared to their previous expectation that they would fall to Rs 1.0 trillion from an all-time high of Rs 1.6 trillion in FYE3/2013.OMCs normally fund their cost of subsidizing fuel prices with short-term borrowings until the government reimburses them 6-9 months later. Furthermore, in the absence of any further diesel price hikes, fuel subsidies would increase an additional Rs 151 billion.To contain thefiscal deficit, the government has introduced a slew of reforms ranging from increase in fuel prices, withdrawing subsidy on diesel sold in bulk and limiting LPG sold at subsidized rates.But a sharp fall in the rupee has reversed the equation for oil marketing companies.A sharp depreciation in the rupee would also result in translation losses on existing foreign-currency borrowings and consequently their balance of foreign-currency borrowings will increase.Moody's estimates the foreign-currency borrowings of the three oil marketing companies at $17.5 bn (Rs 950 bn at a rate of 54.28/USD) as of March 2013, which translates into Rs 1,062 billion at the current exchange rate (INR 60.73/USD), resulting in an increase in debt of Rs 110 billion."]

Author: ['ET Online']
Title: ['HPCL, BPCL, IOC pare gains after firm start']
Content: ['MUMBAI: Shares of oil marketing companies (OMCs), which opened on a positive note after hiking petrol prices late last week, have pared their early gains.OMCs increased petrol price by Rs 1.82 per litre, excluding state levies and taxes with effect from Friday midnight, making it third successive increase in petrol prices as Indianrupeecontinued its free fall against theUS dollar, making the imports costlier."Since last price change, the downwards slide of rupee has continued and the exchange rate has deteriorated from Rs. 57.08 per dollar to Rs 58.94 per dollar during the fortnight. Further, international petrol prices have also increased from $113.84 per barrel to $115.29 per barrel since last price change. The combined impact of both these factors, predominantly of rupee depreciation, has warranted the increase in petrol prices by Rs 1.82 per litre excluding VAT," said an Indian oil Statement.The Rupee last week breached the psychological level of 60 against the US dollar compared to the average price of 57.44 till June 15.The sharp rupee depreciation has nullified the benefits from the decline in fuel subsidies in view of price reforms started in September 2012 and from a near 8 per cent retreat in crude oil prices on a USD basis, says, Moody\'s Investors service said in a report."The rupee depreciation is negative for the state-owned oil marketing companies like -Indian Oil Corporation(IOC, Baa3 stable), Bharat Petroleum Corporation Limited (BPCL, Baa3 stable) andHindustan PetroleumCorporation Limited which continue to import about 70-75 per cent of their crude oil needs and rely heavily on foreign currency borrowings, which largely remain un hedged," the Moody\'s report said.At 09:40 a.m;HPCLedged up 0.02 per cent, BPCL was 0.71 per cent lower and IOC was 0.36 per cent higher.']

Author: ['ByDebjoy Sengupta, ET Bureau']
Title: ['Essar Projects wins its maiden EPC contract from BPCL worth Rs 550 crores']
Subtitle: ['With this the total number of major projects secured by EPL both domestic and overseas has gone up to eight, taking the total order book to about $4.1 bn.']
Content: ['KOLKATA:Essar Projects Limited(EPL), a Global EPC engineering, procurement, construction company headquartered in Dubai, on Tuesday announced that it has secured a contract valued at over Rs 550 crore from Bharat Petroleum Corporation Ltd (BPCL) to participate in its major refinery expansion project in Kochi.EPL has won the contract in a consortium with GR Engineering of Mumbai for the engineering, procurement & construction (EPC) of the reactor regenerator package of 2.2 MMTPA fluid catalytic cracking unit (FCCU) at the Kochi refinery, which is set to expand to 15.5 MMTPA. The project is scheduled to be completed in 24 months.TechnipShaw is the Process Licensor of this package.With this the total number of major projects secured by EPL both domestic and overseas has gone up to eight, taking the total order book to about USD 4.1 billion. EPL is executing significant hydrocarbon projects for major companies like IOCL, Jurong Aeromatics, Matix fertilizers to name a few.Alwyn Bowden, President & CEO,Essar Projectssaid in a statement, "This order from BCPL further consolidates our position in the hydrocarbons sector in India."The scope of work and obligations comprise of project management, residual process design, residual engineering of reactor regenerator, procurement & supply of all materials, stage wise inspection including third party inspection, transportation of all the equipment & materials to work site, erection, installation, pre-commissioning, commissioning, commissioning assistance, testing for performance guarantee in presence of licensor and owner representative etc.On the occasion Amit Gupta- CEO, hydrocarbons business of Essar Projects said, "Essar Projects secured this order amidst extremely stiff competition and demonstrates our competence and capability in delivering complex projects to our key clients in the Hydrocarbons sector."Bharat Petroleum Corporation Limited (BPCL) - Kochi is in the process of expanding the refinery facilities from 9.5 to 15.5 MMTPA as part of the Integrated Refinery Expansion Project (IREP) for which Engineers India Limited (EIL) has been appointed as Project Management Consultant (PMC) for the project.']

Title: ['BHEL wins Rs 2650 million contract from BPCL for Kochi Refinery project']
Content: ["In the face of stiff competition under International Competitive Bidding (ICB), Bharat Heavy Electricals Limited (BHEL) has won a contract for supplying the Gas Turbine Generator package for an energy efficient and environment-friendly co-generation captive power plant at Kochi Refinery in Kerala.Valued at around Rs 2650 Million, the order has been placed on BHEL byBharat Petroleum Corporation Limited(BPCL) for its Integrated Refinery Project (IREP) at Kochi Refinery. The order envisages supply and supervision of 3 nos. Gas Turbines of 34.5 MW rating each, with associated auxiliaries and control systems.The gas turbine will be operated in the cogeneration mode for meeting the power and process steam requirement of the upcoming Kochi refinery expansion project. The customer has opted to source the captive power plant from BHEL in view of its techno-economic superiority - a testimony to the customer's confidence in BHEL's capability.The equiment for the project will be supplied by BHEL's Hyderabad plant and Electronics Division, Bangalore. Erection and commissioning of the Gas Turbine package will be carried out by the company's Power Sector - Southern Region.BHEL has emerged as the market leader in co-generation and captive power plants, offering units from 10 MW onwards for both steam turbine-based and gas-based combined cycle power projects for complete power and process steam requirements of various industries. BHEL offers integrated solutions for captive thermal power plants - be it coal/ oil/ gas fired, combined cycle or open cycle, including co-generation plants, covering the entire range required by industries. The company offers most optimum configurations to suit customer's specific requirements."]

Author: ['ET Online']
Title: ['IOC, BPCL, HPCL can rally over 40% in a year, says Macquarie']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: Theoil marketing companiesnamelyIndian Oil Corporation,BPCL, andHPCLhave fallen 33-42 per cent in the last 3 months as compared toNiftywhich slipped 7 per cent in the same period."AsOMCscontrol 99 per cent of petro-retail and 64 per cent of refining in India, this doomsday expectation is absurd; even if the fiscal is badly stretched," saysMacquarieEquities Research in a report authored by Jal Irani and Abhishek Agarwal.The global investment bank maintains \'outperform\' rating on OMCs and BPCL remains their top pick in the sector.In the month of July, IOCL and HPCL posted losses for the April-June quarter, as delayed and limited government reimbursement and increased interest costs on working capital hurt profits.This was exacerbated byforexlosses due to sharp over 12 per cent INR depreciation against theUS dollar, and weak GRMs.Markets are also concerned on talks of export-parity pricing, which could cut GRMs?However, Macquarie is ofthe viewthat this is infact an opportunity as OMCs cannot share or carry more subsidy burden than at present.Their standalone profits are a reasonably-fixed number which the government plans based on their operational profits, capex needs & the fiscal situation, added the report.The global investment bank is of the view that at present stock prices, OMCs\' legacy subsidy-ridden refining or marketing business are mispriced at sub-4x PE ratios, suggesting that investors expect a 10-20 per cent profit decline to perpetuity.Macquarie believes that the OMCs are at rock-bottom valuations of 0.4-0.7x FY14E P/BV. "We believe that risks of export-parity pricing are overdone; and immaterial for OMCs given their inelastic, bare-minimal profits," the report added.Under-recoveries for the quarter ended June 30 fell to Rs 256 billion, down 30% QoQ, and upstream firms bore their highest-ever share. Macquarie is of the view that OMCs will not bear more than 5 per cent of total yearly subsidy.Forex losses and weak GRMs dragged results for all OMCs; however, BPCL\'s GRMs are higher and more stable than peers (fig 7). Inventory losses for HPCL & IOCL (due to spread-out/east coast refinery locations) also hurt them.']

Author: ['ET Online']
Title: ['ONGC, BPCL, HPCL crack on falling rupee, rising crude oil prices']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: State-ownedoil companiesplunged in morning trade withIOC,HPCL,ONGCandBPCLfalling in the range of 4-6 per cent, weighed by sharp depreciation in therupeeand rising international crude oil prices.The rupee, which has plunged over 10 per cent so far in August, plunged to yet another fresh low of 68 against theUS dollar, weighed by strong month-end dollar demand and uncertainty over Western military action againstSyria.Rising international crude oil prices have taken India\'s cost of importing oil beyond a historic high of Rs 7,000 per barrel which is weighing heavily on state-run firms.Brent crude oil hits 6-month high amid worries a possible military strike by Western powers against Syria could hit Middle Eastern crude supply."Brent had jumped to a 6-month high of $117.23 a barrel by 0345 GMT, while US.crude hit an intraday high of $111.75 - its loftiest since May 2011," Reuters reported.Sharp appreciation in international crude oil prices is bound to increase losses at public sector oil companies as well as further bloat the government\'sbudget deficit, which is already at unsustainable levels, unless diesel prices are revised upwards.At 09:40 a.m.; theBSEOil & Gas index was trading 3.1 per cent lower and was the top most losers among the sectoral indices on the Bombay Stock Exchange.Reliance Industrieswas trading 3.1 per cent lower at Rs 778. It has hit a low of Rs 776.50 and a high of Rs 800 in trade today.Indian Oil Corporationwas down 5 per cent to Rs 195.85.HPCL and ONGC plunged over 7 per cent to hits their respective 52-week lows of 164.50 and 239.05, respectively.BPCL was trading 9 per cent lower at 264.01. The stock has hit a low of Rs 262.10 and a high of Rs 282.50 in trade today.According to analysts, a depreciating rupee and rising international crude oil prices is like a double whammy on oil and gas companies as cost of importing oil beyond a historic high of Rs 7,000 per barrel."The oil import demand is also playing a role as far as the rupee is concerned. Crude oil prices have been going up pretty steeply in the last few weeks and with the rupee depreciating there is a double whammy kind of an impact," said Aditi Nayar, Economist,ICRAin an interview with ET Now.This has put enormous pressure on India\'s current account deficit considering the fact that the country imports nearly 80 per cent of its oil demand, since the government pays for keeping domestic retail prices artificially low."A barrel of crude oil, which India imported for Rs 5,500 per barrel in April 2013, now costs 27 per cent more to over Rs 7,000/barrel, in August," ET reported."The increase is due to a combination of factors - a 7 per cent rise in international crude oil prices and a 19% decline of the rupee against the US dollar," added the report.']

Author: ['ByDebjoy Sengupta, ET Bureau']
Title: ['Essar Projects wins Rs 700 crore contract from BPCL']
Tags: ['EPC', 'EPL', 'BPCL', 'Engineers India', 'Essar Group', 'Bharat Petroleum Corporation Ltd', 'Engineers India Limited']
Subtitle: ['Essar Projects, an EPC company of Essar group, today said it has secured a Rs 700 crore contract from Bharat Petroleum Corporation Ltd (BPCL).']
Content: ['KOLKATA: Essar Projects Limited (EPL), a global engineering, procurement, construction company headquartered in Dubai, announced that it has secured a contract valued at Rs 700 crore from Bharat Petroleum Corporation Limited (BPCL).The order is for Engineering Procurement Construction and Commissioning as well as commissioning assistance (EPCC) of the Coke Drum Structure Package (CDSP) of the Delayed Coker Unit (DCU) at the BPCL Kochi Refinery for the Integrated Refinery Expansion Project.On bagging this project Alwyn Bowden - President & CEO - Essar Projects Limited said, "This is the second award from BPCL this year, reinforcing our commitment to our key customers as we continue to deliver value to their operations."The scope of work includes project management, residual process design, detailed engineering, procurement, fabrication, construction, commissioning, and performance testing of the Coke Drum Structure Package (CDSP) of Delayed Coker Unit for the Client, BPCL.Amit Gupta- CEO, Hydrocarbon SBU- Essar Projects Limited said, "This is the third Coker Unit that Essar Project\'s Hydrocarbon SBU would have setup and this contract is the single largest package of the BPCL Kochi Integrated Refinery Expansion Project."Bharat Petroleum Corporation (BPCL) - Kochi Refinery is in the process of expanding the refinery facilities from 9.5 to 15.5 MMTPA as part of Integrated Refinery Expansion Project (IREP) for whichEngineers India Limited(EIL) has been appointed as Project Management Consultant (PMC) for the project.The DCU has a capacity of 3.84 MMTPA and the process licensor for the unit is M/s. CB&I-; Lummus Technology. The overall project schedule for this project is 27 months, including commissioning.']

Author: ['ET Online']
Title: ['Impact of RBI measures: Rupee at 67/USD; IOC, BPCL, HPCL rally']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: State-run oil marketing companies such asONGC,HPCLandBPCLbounced back with gains of 2-4% in morning trade on Thursday, after the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) opened aforex swap windowfor OMCs to calm volatileforexmarkets.Indianrupeealso managed to bounce back on RBI measures and was trading around sub 67 levels after slipping to a fresh record low of 68.80 per dollar in the previous session. The partial-convertible rupee was trading at 67.20 against theUS Dollar, up 160 paise from its previous close of 68.80 at 09:20 a.m.At 09:20 a.m.; theBSEOil & Gas index was trading 1.03 per cent higher as compared to 0.7 per cent gain in the S&P; BSE Sensex.ONGC rallied over 2.5 per cent in trade totouchits intraday high of Rs 250. The stock pared some of the gains and was trading 1.3 per cent higher at Rs 247.05.BPCL which plunged the most among OMCstocksbounced back over 3 per cent in morning trade today to touch its intraday high of Rs 277. The stock, however, pared some of the gains and was trading 1.2 per cent higher at Rs 272.30.HPCL also rallied over 3 per cent in morning trade after a steep fall in the previous session. The stock was trading 1.2 per cent higher at Rs 165.95.OMC stocks came under considerable pressure in this week weighed down by sharp depreciation in rupee and rising international crude oil prices.According to analysts, a depreciating rupee and rising international crude oil prices are like a double whammy on oil and gas companies as cost of importing oil beyond a historic high of Rs 7,000 per barrel."The oil import demand is also playing a role as far as the rupee is concerned. Crude oil prices have been going up pretty steeply in the last few weeks and with the rupee depreciating there is a double whammy kind of an impact," said Aditi Nayar, Economist,ICRAin an interview with ET Now.This has put enormous pressure on India\'s current account deficit considering the fact that the country imports nearly 80 per cent of its oil demand, since the government pays for keeping domestic retail prices artificially low.To address this issue and reduce volatility in the forex markets the Reserve Bank of India set up a swap window for oil companies to ease the pressure on the battered rupee.Oil companies, which need copious quantities of dollars, can now go to this new window, thereby reducing some of the volatility in the market, ET reported.The central bank will lend dollars to oil marketing companies for equivalent rupees which the marketing companies would return over a period of time."Under the swap facility, the Reserve Bank will undertake sell/buy USD-INR forex swaps for a fixed tenor with the oil marketing companies through a designated bank. The swap facility gets operationalised with immediate effect and will remain in place until further notice," said the central bank in a notification.This is done with an aim to reduce volatility in the rupee market which has been losing ground against the dollar. Rupee has plunged nearly 25 per cent so far in the year 2013.']

Author: ['PTI']
Title: ['Rupee slide to impact IOC, BPCL most: Fitch']
Tags: ['Rupee', 'Inflation', 'BPCL', 'IOC', 'Indian Oil Corporation', 'Indian rupee', 'Bharat Petroleum Corporation Ltd']
Subtitle: ['Global rating agency Fitch said the rupee depreciation will have highest impact on state- owned oil marketing companies, including IOC and BPCL.']
Content: ['NEW DELHI:Global rating agency Fitch on Thursday said therupeedepreciation will have highest impact on state- owned oil marketing companies, includingIOCandBPCL."The risks to standalone financial profiles are highest for state-controlled petroleum marketing companies among the Indian energy sector issuers currently rated by Fitch," it said in a statement.TheIndian rupeehas depreciated by over 27 per cent against the dollar since April 30 (53.80). It closed at a record low of 68.80 yesterday after touching 68.85.Fitch expects limited negative credit implications for most of the rated issuers due to natural or financial hedges or, in the case of utilities, tariff mechanisms that allow for exchange rate fluctuations.The rated oil and gas companies, Fitch said, have a significant proportion of foreign currency-denominated debt.The majority-state owned oil refining and marketing companies -Indian Oil Corporation(IOC) andBharat Petroleum Corporation Ltd(BPCL) - had over 50 per cent of their total debt in foreign currencies in 2012-13 fiscal.Fitch said regular increases in the price of diesel have reduced the under-recoveries, and hence the subsidy requirement, however, the rupee depreciation will reverse this trend."While further price increases for diesel are being considered to reduce the subsidy requirement, the quantum of such price increases remains challenged by pressures on consumerinflationand political dynamics in India," it said.']

Author: ['PTI']
Title: ['Indian Oil, BPCL shares gain after RBI steps, HPCL falls']
Content: ['MUMBAI:Shares ofIndian OilandBharat Petroleumgained today after the Reserve Bank opened a special window to help meet the foreign-exchange requirements of state-owned oil refining companies.Indian Oil shares gained 1.45 per cent to Rs 209.55, while Bharat Petroleum was up 0.45 per cent to Rs 270.05 on theBSE.Hindustan Petroleumfell 0.31 per cent to Rs 163.35.The threestockshad gained as much as 4 per cent in early trade. The benchmark S&P; BSESensexsurged 404.89 points, or 2.25 per cent, to close at 18,401.04.The RBI said in a statement last night that the PSU oil companies could meet their entire daily dollar requirements through a special swap window effective immediately. The three companies are the biggest buyers of dollars in the currency markets, requiring about USD 8.5 billion every month to import an average 7.5 million tonnes of crude oil."RBI\'s latest move to openforexswap window for oil marketing companies to support their daily dollar requirement helped therupeeto strengthen considerably today, which reflected on the equity front as well," said Jayant Manglik, president of retail distribution at Religare Securities.Under the facility, the RBI had said, it will "sell/buy USD-INR forex swaps for fixed tenor with the oil marketing companies through a designated bank." The swap facility will remain in place until further notice, it said.']

Author: ['PTI']
Title: ['JV with LG Chem off, but Kochi petchem project not shelved: BPCL']
Tags: ['BPCL', 'LG Chem', 'Bharat Petroleum', 'R K Singh', 'Numaligarh Refinery', 'Bina refinery', 'Oman Petroleum']
Subtitle: ['"There is no question of shelving the project as this is an  important diversification. We will be the first to make specialty chemicals,"  BPCL said.']
Content: ['MUMBAI:Bharat Petroleumhas said there is no question of shelving its ambitious plan of foraying into niche petrochemicals with the Rs 5,000-crore Kochi petrochemicals project, though its joint venture with Korean majorLG Chemfor the same has reached a dead-end."Yes, it is true that even after inking the MoU with us in July last year, LG Chem has not confirmed its participation in the Kochi petrochemicals project."But let me assure you that there is no plan to shelve the project as we have already started discussions with other companies,"BPCL\'s outgoing Chairman and Managing DirectorR K Singhtold reporters here over the weekend at the post-AGM press briefing.Singh said the talks with the Korean company were at a very advanced stage and there were no differences so far. "It is their decision as there has been no major problem on anything in the MoU. They (LG Chem) are saying the global environment is not very conducive for large investment but it seems they have some other plans and have already made some investment elsewhere," Singh said."There is no question of shelving the project as this is a very important diversification for us. We will be the first company in the country to make specialty chemicals. We are in discussions with other global players who have this particular technology to manufacture the specialty chemicals. We are even open to get the technology licensed to us," he said.Refineries Director B K Datta later told PTI that there are only five companies which have the technology to make speciality propylene derivatives in the world, and BPCL is talking to all of them.No domestic refinery has the technology to make speciality propylene derivatives, and they are being imported now, said Datta.BPCL and LG Chem had inked an MoU to set up the project adjacent to BPCL\'s Kochi refinery complex at an estimated investment of Rs 5,000 crore in July 2012. It was to be a part of the refinery\'s expansion project.Datta said the company has acquired the additional 100 acres of land for the expansion and petchem project, but the green nod for the petchem project is awaited.BPCL currently has four refineries in the country - the 12 MT Mumbai facility, the 9.5 MT Kochi plant, the 6 MTBina refineryin MP which is a JV withOman Petroleum, and the 3 MTNumaligarh refineryin Assam.']

Author: ['ET Online']
Title: ['Moily defers diesel price hike; HPCL, BPCL slip over 4%']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: The BSEOil& Gas Index came under pressure on Wednesday and was the second largest loser among theBSEsectoral indices, after the BSE Banking Index, as sentiment turned bearish after oil minister Veerappa Moily ruled out any sharp increase indieselprices in the near future."As of now there is no proposal to raise prices," Moily told reporters after announcing the launch of a mega fuel conservation campaign to cut the country\'s rising fuel subsidy bill.At 01:30 pm, the BSE Oil & Gas Index was trading 2 per cent lower, led by losses inBPCL,HPCL, which plunged over 4 per cent, while GAIL, Petronet LNG,IOCandReliance Industrieswere trading 1-4 per cent lower.Bharat Petroleum was the biggest loser on the BSE Oil & Gas Index and on the 50-shareNiftyindex. The stock plunged as much as 5.8 per cent in trade today.HPCL which dropped a little over 4 per cent in trade managed to recover marginally and was trading 3.4 per cent lower at Rs 187.30. Reliance Industries was trading 3.2 per cent lower at Rs 845.95 andIndian Oil Corporationdropped 1.8 per cent to Rs 215.40.An ET report quoting Moily said that revenue losses of state oil marketing companies on diesel have jumped to Rs 14.50 a litre mainly because of depreciation of therupee. "We are concerned about the under-recoveries (revenue losses). We are working on other alternatives to reduce the under-recoveries," he said."Honestly, it will all depend on the international crude prices and the rupee-dollar equation going forward. However, purely on the fundamentals, the postponement of the diesel price hike to December has disappointed themarketsto a great extent," said Gaurang Shah of GeojitBNP ParibasFinancial Services in an interview with ET Now."Amongst all the three oil marketing companies that you\'ve named, as a disclosure we have a positive bias towards BPCL, purely on the fundamental side," he added.Shah hopes that the crude prices will move down and they well see some strength coming back into the rupee against the dollar.']

Author: ['PTI']
Title: ['IOCL, BPCL and HPCL move Supreme Court for modification of Aadhaar order']
Tags: ['Natural gas', 'Supreme Court', 'Nageshwar Rao', 'BPCL', 'HPCL', 'Ministry of petroleum and natural gas', 'UIDAI']
Subtitle: ['DBTL has already been implemented and has been running successfully in 54 districts and the old system of subsidy has been stopped.']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: Three oil PSUs have moved theSupreme Courtseeking modification of its earlier order that Aadhaar card is not mandatory and no person should suffer for want of it in getting benefits of government schemes.IOCL,BPCLandHPCLwould mention the matter on Monday for urgent hearing before a bench of Chief Justice P Sathasivam and JusticeRanjan Gogoiwhich has already listed a similar plea ofMinistry of PetroleumandNatural Gas(MOPNG) for consideration on October 8.Khushbu Jain, counsel for the PSUs, said Additional Solicitor GeneralNageshwar Raowould mention the plea before the bench as the earlier order has created "serious doubts, confusion and uncertainty" in the minds of citizens who have already enrolled for Aadhaar card to avail Direct Benefit Transfer for Liquefied Petroleum Gas Consumers (DBTL) scheme to get subsidised LPG cylinders.DBTL has already been implemented and has been running successfully in 54 districts and the old system of subsidy has been stopped, the PSUs said, adding that the firms are in process of implementing the scheme in 235 other districts.Earlier, the apex court agreed to hear on October 8 the plea of MOPNG that has sought "clarification or modification" of the order for continuing with its DBTL scheme which can be availed only by those persons who have secured Aadhaar cards.A bench headed by Justice B S Chauhan had on September 23 said, "In the meanwhile, no person should suffer for not getting the Aadhaar card in spite of the fact that some authority had issued a circular making it mandatory and when any person applies to get the Aadhaar card voluntarily, it may be checked whether that person is entitled for it under the law and it should not be given to any illegal immigrant."The order had come during the hearing of a PIL filed by Justice K Puttaswamy, former high court judge, seeking to restrain the Centre, Planning Commission and the Unique Identification Authority of India (UIDAI) from issuing Aadhaar cards by way of an executive order of January 28, 2009.The MOPNG, in its plea, had said the Aadhaar card was not necessary for the consumers who want to purchase unsubsidised LPG cylinders from the oil companies, but it is necessary for supply of subsidised cylinders in 54 districts in the country."Keeping in mind the objectives for which the DBTL scheme has been launched and implemented and the absolute necessity of the Aadhaar card to ensure its successful implementation, this court may be pleased to clarify or modify its order dated 23.09.2013 to state that while no one may be denied domestic LPG cylinders at market rates in the absence of Aadhaar cards, the Aadhaar card may be allowed to be mandatorily sought by the MOPNG to make subsidy payments to those entitled to the same under the DBTL scheme with a view to eliminate diversion of subsidised cylinders into black market," the plea had said."The DBTL scheme has been launched to ensure that the LPG consumers\' entitlement is not diverted and to prevent leakage in the LPG subsidy. The LPG subsidy amounted to Rs 39,558 crores during 2012-13," it said.It said the average market price of a domestic LPG cylinder is Rs 943.36 and the retail price of the same is Rs 410.50 and "the subsidy works out to Rs 555.55 per subsidised cylinder," adding that to avoid diversion of funds, the modification of the order was needed.']

Author: ['ByNarendra Nathan, ET Bureau']
Title: ['Improved refining margins, high potential make BPCL a safe stock bet']
Content: ["BPCLhas once again managed to buck the trend among PSU oil marketing companies by reporting a net profit of Rs 150 crore during the April-June quarter, even as its peers?IOC and HPCL?were forced to report losses. More importantly, BPCL's gross refining margins (GRM) are higher and more stable compared with those of its PSU peers, indicating better operational structure.The company's recently commissioned Bina refinery is of greater complexity and, therefore, generates higher GRMs. BPCL is also increasing its capacity/complexity levels in its Kochi refinery, and when completed, this should boost its revenue/refining margins significantly.Its chemical project withLGChemicals to manufacture high-value adsorbents is another factor that will increase its profitability in the coming years. One reason that the analysts are showing an increased interest in the company is that it'sinvestmentsin the oil and gas exploration field have started yielding results. As of now, it has a stake in 25 blocks in 16 countries. Among them, the blocks in Mozambique and Brazil, partnering Anadarko andPetrobras, have significant potential.The recent discoveries in its Mozambique and Brazil fields should help the company derisk its business from the volatility of oil marketing. The recent deals suggest that its assets in the Mozambique fields are world-class and in line with the deal; BPCL's 10% stake is estimated to be worth $ 2.5 billion.Even though it is the best player among the PSU oil marketing companies and a good long-term bet, it is not free of the regulatory woes plaguing the sector. For instance, the threat of export parity pricing, which will potentially wipe out the entire profits of oil marketing companies, is still hanging over the sector. Similarly, the proposed one-time price increase to reduce the under-recovery in diesel is off the table, and may not happen till the ongoing assembly elections are complete.Though the monthly diesel price increases of 45 paisa per litre is continuing, there is risk associated with it during the upcoming national elections. So, investors should buy this stock with a 3- to 5-year view.Selection methodology: We choose the stock that has shown the maximum improvement in consensus analyst rating over the past month. Consensus rating is arrived at by averaging all analyst recommendations after attributing weightages to each (5 for strong buy, 4 for buy, 3 for hold, 2 for sell and 1 for strong sell).Any improvement in consensus rating indicates that analysts are becoming more bullish on the stock. To make sure that we pick only companies that are widely covered, this search will be restricted tostocksthat are covered by at least 10 analysts."]

Author: ['PTI']
Title: ['Oil discovery in BPCL-Videocon block in Brazil']
Subtitle: ['A significant oil discovery has been made in an ultra-deep water block off Brazil where BPCL and Videocon Industries together hold 40 per cent interest.']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: A significantoil discoveryhas been made in an ultra-deep water block offBrazilwhere state- owned Bharat Petroleum Corp Ltd (BPCL) andVideocon Industriestogether hold 40 per cent interest.Brazilian oil giantPetrobras, which is the operator of the block, has confirmed the Farfan-1 oil discovery in the ultra-deep waters of the Segipe-Alagoas basin, off Brazil, Videocon said in a statement.The state-owned firm has confirmed excellent productivity of good quality crude following a drilling test.Petroleo Brasileiro SA (Petrobras) has completed a test in well 3-BRSA-1178D-SES (3-SES-176D), informally known as Farfan 1, to test the production capacity of the accumulation in the BM-SEAL-11 concession area of Block SEAL-M-426.Based on an evaluation of 30 metres of turbidite sandstones, the test found good quality oil with a density of 38 degrees API in a "good" reservoir with "excellent productivity", the statement said.Farfan-1 is located 104 km north of Aracaju, the capital of the north-eastern Brazilian state of Sergipe. It lies in a water depth of 2476 metres, about 5 km from the Farfan discovery well.Petrobras is the operator of the block with a 60 per cent interest while IBV Brasil (a 50:50 joint venture of BPCL and Videocon) holds the remaining 40 per cent stake.A 51-metre reservoir was discovered at Farfan-1 well, a year after a 44-metre hydrocarbon column was found in Farfan a year ago.The discovery has been estimated to hold more than 1 billion barrels of oil.Petrobras chief executiveMariadas Gracas Foster had previously said the BM-SEAL-11 concession could produce at least 100,000 barrels per day of oil, starting in 2018.']

Title: ["Here's why BPCL, ONGC look promising bets on every decline"]
Tags: ['Bharat Petroleum Corp Ltd', 'ONGC', 'NTPC', 'Coal India', 'Videocon Industries', 'Mozambique', 'Oil India Ltd']
Content: ["By D K AggarwalOverseas asset purchases by the cash rich public sector units (PSU) were not easy in the past amidst competition from neighbouring China and policy paralysis within the country. In this tough scenario, whatever acquisitions they have made in the past have started to garner fruitful results. Oil PSUs in India have to battle with bigger and economically stronger Chinese firms in the chase for resources abroad.The public sector units in India were faced with procedures which are really cumbersome and time-consuming. By the time they get the clearance, the deal is already been taken by the competing nations or individual entrepreneurs. However realizing the limited domestic natural resources and importance of availability of raw material are prerequisites not only for the growth of the manufacturing sector alone, but for the economy as a whole, the policy makers in India unveiled a new policy in 2011 which accords greater independence to PSUs in their overseas acquisitions.Of late the government is also mulling setting up a new company, loosely modelled on the concept of a sovereign wealth fund, to finance the acquisition of natural resource assets abroad. The proposed Indian Overseas Investment Corp Ltd (INOIC) will be wholly owned by the government and administered by the Ministry of Finance. INOIC will invest in ownership of natural resource assets overseas. It will be a development finance institution with the mandate to provide equity and debt to public sector companies to secure natural resources abroad.Heavy weight PSUs such as ONGC, BPCL, coal India and NTPC have ventured into the foreign assets acquisitions in a significant manner in the last few years. ONGC Videsh Limited (OVL), a wholly owned subsidiary of ONGC, has stake in 32 oil and gas projects in 16 countries such as Vietnam, Russia, Sudan, Iran and Brazil.Till January 2013, BPCL has a total of 17 discoveries out of which eight are in Mozambique, six in Brazil and one each in India, Indonesia and Australia. Recently a significant oil discovery has been made in an ultra-deep water block off Brazil where state-owned Bharat Petroleum Corp Ltd (BPCL) and Videocon Industries together hold 40 per cent interest. The discovery has been estimated to hold more than 1 billion barrels of oil. BPCL has also entered into the arena of shale gas in 2010 with acquisition of interest in a block with shale gas potential in the Perth basin in Australia.The recent trend of overseas acquisitions by the cash rich PSUs is likely to gather further momentum in the near future considering the amount of cash available in their books and initiatives taken by the policy makers. Oil giants such as ONGC Videsh Limited (OVL) and Oil India Ltd (OIL) are making speedy pace in overseas soils in their efforts to discover more oil fields to meet nation's growing energy needs. Meanwhile India's second biggest state-owned explorer OIL has already formed an overseas subsidiary to look after its assets abroad."]
