Author: ['ByNarendra Nathan, ET Bureau']
Title: ["Low crude oil prices help BPCL's marketing business, make analysts bullish on stock"]
Subtitle: ['BPCL has been a major beneficiary of the fall in crude oil prices and the resultant fall in underrecoveries in petroleum products.']
Content: ['Bharat Petroleum Corp (BPCL) has relatively stable refining margins and, therefore, it rarely surprises the market negatively. With a 46% jump in net profit,BPCLhas, once again, met market expectations in the third quarter of 2015-16. A significant spike in the gross refining margin (GRM) and the resultant 81% year-on-year (y-o-y) increase in earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation were the main highlights of its third quarter results.Like otheroil marketing companies(OMCs), BPCL too has been a major beneficiary of the fall in crude oil prices and the resultant fall in underrecoveries in petroleum products. The government has already capped its subsidy burden at Rs 12 per litre for kerosene and Rs 18 per kg for LPG. After realising the success of Aadhaar card-linked direct benefit transfer (DBT) scheme in providing the LPG subsidy, the government has started implementing DBT on a pilot basis for giving out kerosene subsidy. That means, if crude oil doesn?t move up significantly from the current level, there won?t be any subsidy burden for OMCs in 2016-17.The domestic oil demand has increased in the recent past due to the fall in prices. The domestic sales volume in the third quarter of 2015-16 went up 8% y-o-y on the back of a strong demand for petrol and diesel. The recent push for the road sector in the Budget should further boost demand for petrol and diesel in the coming years.Unlike other OMCs, BPCL has a significant exposure to overseas oil and gas fields. While the company is doing an appraisal of its assets in Brazil, it?s subsidiary is expected toinvestaround $100 million (over Rs 670 crore) in calendar year 2016 in an oil field in Mozambique in which BPCL has around 10% stake. The current low oil and gas prices should help BPCL?s overseas ventures get fater clearances and at a lower cost. Since the current level at which crude is trading is not sustainable in the long term, prices are expected to recover in the next 2-3 years, by the time these field become operational. However, BPCL will be negatively impacted if crude oil prices remain this low for an extended period.Unlike other OMCs, BPCL is valued using the sum of parts (SOP) valuation method and analysts peg the valuation for its overseas upstream projects at around Rs 200 per share. Since these overseas ventures are yet not operational and thus not making profits, their impact won?t be captured in valuation ratios such as PE. This is one reason why it looks like the stock is quoting at premium valuation compared to its peers.Selection Methodology:We pick the stock that has shown the maximum increase in ?consensus analyst rating? in the past one month. Consensus rating is arrived at by averaging all analyst recommendations after attributing weights to each of them (5 for strong buy, 4 for buy, 3 for hold, 2 for sell and 1 for strong sell) and any improvement in consensus analyst rating indicates that the analysts are getting more bullish on the stock. To make sure that we pick only companies with decent analyst coverage, this search is restricted tostocksthat are covered by at least 10 analysts. You can see similar consensus analyst rating changes during the past week in the ETW 50 table.']

Author: ['ET Bureau']
Title: ['Indian Oil Corporation, Oil India and Bharat Petroleum to buy 29.9% in Rosneft field for $1.3 billion']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: Indian Oil Corporation,Oil IndiaandBharat PetroleumCorporation have agreed to buy 29.9 per cent stake in Rosneft?s Taas-Yuryakh field in Russia for $1.3 billion. Rosneft has also signed preliminary agreements with Indian firms that could take the country?s stake to nearly 50 per cent in Vankor, the second largest oil field in Russia, cementing energy ties between India and Russia."The cooperation formula, designed at the corporate level, is aimed at the creation of vertically integrated model, allowing India partners to participate in the upstream sector, whilst opening the growing India market to Rosneft," said Igor Sechin, CEO of Rosneft. Following the agreement, Rosneft will retain the majority stake in the joint venture managing the Taas-Yuryakh field, in which BP PLc has 20 per cent stake."Price parameters of the transaction with Indian companies are similar to the terms of the agreement which BP signed at the St Petersburg Economic Forum in June 2015," Rosneft said in a statement. A source, however, placed the transaction value at $1.3 billion, which comprises a cash outgo of $1.12 billion and a commitment of 180 million in capital spending over the next three years. The field has a proven reserve of 137 million metric tonne, the source said.The field is currently producing 20,000 barrels per day of oil and is expected to touch a peak of 100,000 barrels a day in 2021. "The acquisition is subject to relevant board, government and regulatory approvals and is expected to close by September 2016," Indian Oil Corp said in a statement.Attracting strategic investors will give additional momentum to the development of the field, one of the largest oil and gas condensate fields in East Siberia, Rosneft said.The three state firms also signed preliminary agreements with Rosneft to acquire 23.9 per cent stake in the Vankor field in Russia, the nation?s second largest field by output making for 4 per cent of Russian production. The field is engaged in a peak production of about 440,000 barrels a day.Rosneft has entered into similar agreement with Oil and Natural Gas Corporation to raise the latter?s stake to 26 per cent in the Vankor field from 15 per cent now. If the two deals go through, it would take Indian stake to 49.9 per cent in Vankor.ONGC had purchased 15 per cent stake in Vankor last year for $1.27 billion. "Oil prices have substantially fallen since then. So, the previous prices are no more valid for fresh stakes. We will have to renegotiate prices," said a state oil firm executive. The companies have about three months to complete the due diligence, he said.Oil India, Indian Oil Corp and Bharat Petroleum Corp have also entered into another preliminary agreement with Rosneft to acquire stake in what is referred to as Vankor cluster or the explored satellite fields around Vankor.']

Author: ['ByAshutosh Shyam, ET Bureau']
Title: ['HPCL, BPCL, IOC stocks to witness another round of price-earnings re-rating']
Content: ['ET INTELLIGENCE GROUP: Thestocksof oil marketing corporations (OMCs) ? Indian Oil,Hindustan Petroleumand Bharat Petroleum ? could see another round of price-earnings (PE) multiples re-rating as historical baggage such as the extent of the burden of oil subsidies and fluctuations in marketing margins that lead toearningsvolatility are gradually diminishing.The three state-run companies are trading 30-50% cheaper than the regional average. As the headwinds for the earnings are evaporating and deregulation sustains in the face of increasing crude prices, PE multiples could expand and the valuation gap with peers narrow. With five states going for elections in the next two months, investors expect OMCs to have limited ability to revise prices in tandem with the increase in crude oil prices.This will impact their marketing margins, or the amount they get over the cost incurred to produce final petroleum products. Analysts consider Rs 1.5 per litre as a fair marketing margin for petrol and diesel. However, the OMCs increased prices by Rs 3.1 and Rs 1.9 per litre on petrol and diesel, respectively in the past week, in line with the increase in the international crude prices.This will assuage investors? concern that these companies may refrain from revising prices due to political compulsions. After the price revision, the average marketing margins will be about Rs 2 on diesel and Rs 2.2 on petrol in the fourth quarter FY16 compared to Rs 1.4 and Rs 2, respectively in the preceding quarter, according to analysts? estimates. The earnings from the marketing division contribute 30-65% of the total operating profits of OMCs.Any dip below the fair marketing margins leads to a sizeable cut in the profits. The government and the OMCs have built buffer to lowersubsidyburden in case crude prices flare up. This has raised hopes that these companies may not have to bear oil subsidy burden in the current and the next fiscal. In the Budget, the government has considered incrementalexcise dutygain of Rs 34,500 crore.However, calculated on the basis of exit rate of excise collection in FY16, the government could have garnered an additional Rs 80,000 crore. This implies that the government may consider cutting excise duty if crude prices continue to rise. Similarly, the OMCs have built a buffer of nearly Rs 8,500 crore on selling liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) as actual under-recoveries per cylinder were less than subsidy received from the government.This will help lower subsidy burden in case the government passes on some subsidy burden and protect additional under-recoveries till crude oil prices reach $52 per barrel. Besides, Q4 earnings of these companies are likely to improve as inventory losses in the preceding quarter are likely to reverse.The stocks are trading at 5.5-7.3 times their projected earnings growth against the regional average of 10 times. As the overhang of earnings uncertainties fades, the gap between the local companies and their regional peers may narrow.']

Author: ['BySanjeev Choudhary, ET Bureau']
Title: ['BPCL plans to spend Rs 10,000 crore to boost its refining capacity']
Subtitle: ['India?s second biggest state refiner, plans to spend about Rs 10,000 crore in 2016-17 to expand and upgrade its refining capacity.']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: Bharat Petroleum Corporation (BPCL), India?s second biggest state refiner, plans to spend about Rs 10,000 crore in 2016-17 to expand and upgrade its refining capacity and augment its marketing infrastructure, itsfinancechief has said.?We need toinvestin infrastructure to meet the growing demand in the market,? said P Balasubramanian, director (finance) at BPCL, which has made about Rs 9,500 crore in capital expenditure in the current fiscal year. Indian refiners and fossil fuel retailers have been working on adding new capacity to cater to the rapidly rising fuel demand in the country.The petroleum product consumption had grown by 10% till January this fiscal year. An expansion underway at Kochi refinery will take about 40% of the BPCL?s planned capex for 2016-17. The refinery is adding 6 million tonne per annum (MTPA) to the existing capacity of 9.5 MTPA. BPCL?s total capacity is about 27.5 million tonne.Another Rs 1,000 crore would go towards upgrading other refineries to help them produce higher grade fuels that meet Euro IV and VI emission norms. The government wants all state refiners to make available Euro IV fuels across the country next year and Euro VI by 2020.About Rs 1,000 crore would be utilised by the company?s upstream business managed by Bharat Petroresources that has just bought nearly 10% stake in an east Siberian field owned by Rosneft. The balance funds would be deployed in building a petrochemicals unit, pipelines, marketing terminals and depots, and procuring cooking gas cylinders.BPCL wouldn?t need to raise fresh funds and would rely on internal resources and the previously-tied up borrowings to finance the planned capex, Balasubramanian said. BPCL and other state firms are now facing tough competition from the private sector in the key fuel retailing business and need to invest more to strengthen their position in the market.?The biggest challenge is to retain and grow themarket sharewith growing competition, and meeting customer expectation in the industry,? he said. In a year after the deregulation of diesel sales,Reliance Industries, Essar Oil and Shell have together taken about 4% in petrol and diesel volumes across the country and threaten to gobble more quickly with their price discounts and other promotional efforts.An ambitious target set by the government to add about 10 crore cooking gas consumers in three years, or about 60% of the current base, means distributors like BPCL will have to invest heavily in setting up import and distribution terminals and bottling plants as well as in purchasing more gas cylinders.']

Author: ['ByRajesh Mascarenhas, ET Bureau']
Title: ['BPCL likely to see foreign funds buying shares of around Rs 1,008 crore']
Content: ['MUMBAI: Investors are mounting bets on state-ownedBPCLafter the company approved the increase in ceiling of investment for foreign institutional investors (FIIs) from 24% to 49%. This move, once approved by the shareholders and regulators, could result in FII inflow of over Rs 1,000 crore into the stock, according to analysts.Currently, BPCL has 0.41basis points weightage on the MSCI EmergingMarketIndex. After the ceiling on FII investment goes up to 49% from 24%, the weight of BPCL in MSCI index is expected to increase to 1.22%. This will result in foreign fund managers buying around 11 crore shares worth Rs 1,008 crore at Tuesday\'s closing price.Shares of BPCL have surged nearly 4.5% since April 1 and 15% in the past one month against gains of 1.4% and 3.3% by theSensexin the respective periods. The stock has seen sharp long position build-up since beginning of April following its breakout above its 200-day moving average, a key sentiment indicator."The stock continues to see an uptrend with long build-up to the tune of 11% in fresh open interest seen from the start of the April series. The stock has made strong gains with highs near the Rs 942 zone which is crucial spinning top seen in the December and January series at same levels," said Navneet Daga, head of derivatives,IIFL.BPCL, which closed at Rs 925.45 on Wednesday, is one of the top picks of many brokerages."Ongoing reforms have the potential to transform oil marketing companies into a structural investment play. BPCL stands out among OMCs for its superior RoE of 23% in FY15," said Raamdeo Agrawal, Joint MD,Motilal Oswal Financial Services.For the nine month ended December 2015, company reported an 11.9% jump in earnings per share to Rs 67.5. Analysts are forecasting an EPS of Rs 82 per share in 2015-16."With multiple earnings catalysts, BPCL is a beneficiary of reforms/lower oil prices, which is likely to see margin expansion," said Niel Gupte, analyst,JP Morganin a recent note."BPCL also offers value from an emerging E&P; portfolio - justifying premium valuations."']

Author: ['ByRajesh Mascarenhas, ET Bureau']
Title: ['OMCs likely to post strong numbers for March quarter; CLSA hikes target price on HPCL, BPCL & IOC']
Content: ['MUMBAI: Oil marketing companies (OMCs) such asHPCL,IOCandBPCLare likely to post strong numbers for the March quarter and also for the full year, amid lower crude prices, weakerrupee, less inventory losses and better marketing margins, said analysts. This is the first full year earnings for OMCs post diesel deregulation in 2014.Analysts expect an average of 33-153% growth in operating profit, and 36-240% in net profit for the full year ended March 2016."Elimination of inventory losses and higher marketing margins should ensure a strong Q4 for OMCs," saidCLSAon Wednesday. "Building in higher GRMs, weak rupee and lower crude, we raise FY16-18 EPS estimates for all three by 2-26% and targets by 8-22%."CLSA, while maintaining its buy rating, has increased its target price for IOC to Rs 540, BPCL to Rs 1,130, and HPCL to Rs 1,020.While the HPCL stock has surged 52% from its 52-week low, BPCL and IOC have bounced back 36% and 30%, respectively, but analysts still feel that valuations are very attractive."Financial performance of OMCs has been largely normalised with RoEs at 18-24%," said Harshad Borawake, research analyst,Motilal OswalSecurities. "Current valuations do not reflect multiple levers of sustained earnings growth and higher return ratios for OMCs."OMCs are currently trading at FY18 estimated PE of 5-8 times, compared with their 5-year average PE of 13-22 times. Also, their estimated dividend yield for FY17 is 3.5-4.5%.On the other hand, India\'s oil demand for Q4 grew 14.5% YoY against 8.5% in 2015. This is the seventh consecutive month the three-month rolling tracker has shown double-digit demand growth. "We remain positive on OMCs as every percentage point of volume growth helps EPS by 1.5%," said Badrinath Srinivasan of Credit Suisse.']

Author: ['PTI']
Title: ['BPCL gets green nod for Rs 694 crore LPG project in West Bengal']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: State-owned fuel retailer BPCL has got green nod for its Rs 694-crore project of developingLPGimport terminal as well as storage, bottling and bulk distribution facilities at Haldia Dock Complex inWest Bengal.At present, domestic production of LPG is around 12.38 millionmetrictonne per annum (mmtpa), much lower than the estimated demand of 18.65 mmtpa for this year. The proposed project aims to boost supply and help achieve the government\'s target of making LPG available to each household by 2018."Based on the recommendations of the Expert Appraisal Committee (industry), theenvironmentministry has given environmental clearance and CoastalRegulationZone (CRZ) clearance to the BPCL\'s project in West Bengal," a senior government official said.The green nod is subject to certain specific and general conditions, the official said.The proposed project will ensure LPG supplies to far-flung areas of eastern and north-eastern regions and will create an infrastructure to import the eco-friendly LPG fuel, the official added.As per the proposal, Bharat Petroleum Corporation (BPCL) will set up an import terminal at Haldia to import 1 mmtpa of refrigerated Propane and Butane and transfer it through 7.5-km long twin transfer pipeline for LPG production, despatch of bulk LPG via road tankers and bottling of LPG in cylinders.The proposal also includes setting up of a bottling plant comprising two LPG-mounded bullet storage facility of 350 tonnes capacity each, besides loading facilities, allied machineries, loading gantries for bulk tanker and filled cylinder despatch through road within the land allotted.The estimated cost of the proposed project is Rs 694 crore, which is to be completed in a year from the date of award of the environment clearance.BPCL, one of India\'s four major integrated petroleum refining and marketing companies, produces a diverse range of products from petrochemicals and solvents to aircraft fuel and specialty lubricants.The companymarketsits products through its wide network of petrol stations, kerosene dealers, LPG distributors, besides supplying fuel directly to hundreds of industries, and several international and domestic airlines.']

Author: ['PTI']
Title: ['Government allows BPCL to pump in more equity into Bina refinery']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: With Oman Oil Company reluctant to put more money, the government today allowed Bharat Petroleum Corp Ltd (BPCL) to fund the Rs 3,000-crore expansion of Bina refinery in Madhya Pradesh by putting in more equity.BPCL, India\'s second-biggest state refiner, plans to raise Bina refinery capacity in two phases - to 7.8 million tonnes a year from current six million tonnes at a cost of Rs 3,072 crore by 2018 and then to 15 million tonnes at an additional investment of Rs 18,000-20,000 crore in five-six years.The Cabinet chaired by Prime Minister Narendra Modi gave its approval to enhance investment by BPCL in Bharat Oman Refineries Limited (BORL) for the first phase of expansion."The investment amount could be enhanced up to a maximum of Rs 3000 crore by way of subscription of convertible warrants / other instruments giving right to convert it into equity shares to be issued by BORL," an official statement said.The infusion of funds, it said, will enable BORL to overcome the implications on account of the erosion of the net worth.The expansion will enhance the availability of petroleum products in the northern and central parts of the country.Oman Oil Company (OCC), which holds 26 per cent stake in the Bharat Oman Refineries (BORL) -- the firm that built the refinery -- is unwilling to participate in the expansion.OCC in 2009 paid a 50 per cent premium for a re-entry into the Rs 11,397-crore Bina refinery project. The project was originally conceived through a joint venture company, BORL but the OCC did not contribute equity beyond the initial Rs 75 crore.The Omanese oil major came back to pick up 26 per cent stake in the project for an additional Rs 1,220 crore.The BORL was formed as an equal joint venture company way back in 1993. However, following inordinate delays in the implementation of the project, OOC froze its investment in the company at Rs 75 crore for a two per cent equity stake.BPCL, which holds 49 per cent stake in the project, provided the unbridged portion of the Rs 4,000-crore equity in form of loan. The state-run firm got its loan back once OOC made payments for its 26 per cent share.The remaining 25 per cent is with financial institutions.The expansion will help the refinery to produce petrol and diesel confirming to Euro-VI norm."OOC while expressing their support for the project, had indicated that they are not prepared to commit further funds for the project at this stage. Therefore, BPCL Board has decided to infuse funds to the tune of Rs 3,000 crore for funding the debottlenecking project and for meeting the extraordinary losses suffered on account of the sharp fall in the prices of crude oil and finished products," the statement said.BPCL also operates a 12 million tonnes a year refinery at Mumbai and 9.5 million tonnes Kochi unit. It also has majority stakes in the three million tonnes Numaligarh refinery in Assam.']

Author: ['ET Online']
Title: ['BPCL surges on hopes of Exxon-ENI deal even as Q4 NP slips 10.6%']
Content: ["NEW DELHI: Shares of state-owned Bharat Petroleum Corporation (BPCL) ended 8.48 per cent higher on Friday on hopes that the ENi-Exxon deal will raise the value of its Mozambique oil assets.The company owns Area one oilfield in Mozambique, whose valuation has hit low single digit in a low crude priceenvironment. Author: ['ET Now']
Title: ['Refinery margins have been 65% of total revenue: P Balasubramanian, BPCL']
Content: ["In a chat withET Now, P Balasubramanian, Director-Finance,BPCL, says marketing margins have started picking up and overall the margins have been good at both refining and marketing levels. Edited excerptsETNow: BPCL's gross refining margins (GRMs) were strong and in terms of operational efficiencies, you have delivered another strong quarter. So walk us through the key highlights both on the GRM front and on the operational front.P Balasubramanian:Overall, the GRMs for the year has been excellent and that is one of the reasons why we had given excellent results. We have our annual GRM for the year at is around 6.59, that is almost $3 more than last year's. So that has been one of the highlights of this year's performance. The second one is that in the marketing side, we have increased our sales and have actually sold almost two million tonnes more than what we did last year. So these are the two main things which are the key drivers for our profits during the current year. Of course, it is supplemented with no underrecovery compensation to be shared by the OMCs. So 100 per cent compensation has been received. So better working capital management, along with these things, have given us the impetus to have excellent performance during the current year.ET Now: Is there any inventory gain though?P Balasubramanian: This year, there was an inventory loss and there were no inventory gains in the current year because crude has moved down further during the current year.ET Now: How much of the strength has come in because of the good refining margins and how much due to the marketing margins if you could give me a breakup of that?P Balasubramanian: Normally, the refining and marketing margins used to be around 50-50 range. This year, because of the excellent performance of the refineries, the refinery margins have been almost around 65 per cent of the total revenue.ET Now: Your volumes have been very robust as well this quarter. Almost 6.2MThigher both on year on year on basis as well as on a sequential basis. How much growth are you witnessing in each of your products? If you could give me highlights, which one would you say is the fastest growing one for you?P Balasubramanian: See the fastest growing product this year has been the petrol which has grown almost around 12.3 per cent in the current year. Overall, the industry growth of petrol is very high in the current year. Of course, it is supplemented by the diesel price increase also. So both put together, has given us good growth in the current year. Actually after a lot of years of stagnating growth in the petroleum sector, this year has seen an excellent growth. So that has really helped sector to do very well.ET Now: Let us talk about the current scenario and crude is at $50 once again. So at $50 per barrel, are you making money in your marketingbusiness?P Balasubramanian:Of course, we are making money at marketing business. Marketing margins are still continue to be around Rs 1800 and diesel is around Rs 1500 per KL. So that continues and on the refining side, the margins were slightly lower compared to Q4 because the crack price of diesel has come down a little. But, of course, it is picking up and it is a matter of early days for the margins to settle but yes, overall the margins have been good both at the refining and marketing level.ET Now: Would you say that GRMs are plateauing or peaking at all?P Balasubramanian: No the growth of diesel in the last couple of fortnights have been very good. The overall demand in the Asian side is very good as far as diesel is concerned. So I think the cracks of diesel will be somewhere around $10 plus for the year as an average. But yes, it is early days yet. We have to wait and watch where the cracks settle at the end of the period.ET Now: Can you give me a sense of your projected cash flow for FY17 because for the longest time, BPCL has not been in expansion mode because the sector was not deregulated. Now the sector is deregulated, you are making money, what would be your projected cash flow?P Balasubramanian: In BPCL, as a company, we have been having excellent capex programme for the last three years. We are expanding. We have commissioned our refinery atMumbaiand the woork on the Kochi refinery is on track. We have spent almost Rs 10,000 crore in 2014-15, more than Rs 10,000 crore in the current year that is 2015-16 and we have capex plan of around Rs 12,000-15,000 crore next year (2016-17) depending upon how the projects come. Of course, major portion of the next year's expenditure will be on our completion of the refinery at Kochi.ET Now: What will be your total refining capacity by end of FY18?P Balasubramanian:It will be around 40 million tonnes.ET Now: And you think the capacity utilisation will be 100 per cent right from inception?P Balasubramanian:Indiais growingmarket. Even if we grow at 5 per cent per annum, we require eight million tonne refining capacity every year. Of course, India is long on refining and we have some extra capacities in case of private refiners but having said that, even that capacity can be absorbed if the growth momentum continues to be around 5 per cent plus in the next three, four years and again we have had to make investments on the refining side again.ET Now: I want a number from you this quarter. You have done 6.3 on GRMs but from here on in the near term, what range do you see your margins coming in at? Can they dip slightly in the near term or do you think you will always be able to beat the 6.3 mark?P Balasubramanian: Last year has been an exceptional year for the refiners. The refinery margins have been excellent last year. We hope that the current year will also give us a decent margin ranging between $4 and $6. Currently the margins are almost roughly around $5 per barrel. But we have to wait and watch how the whole thing spans out because this is a global demand and supply scenario and not only on the domestic market side.ET Now: Recently there were reports that ENI may be selling stake to Exxon in the Mozambique block. You also have a stake there. So do you see possibility of any merger or acquisition there and if yes the valuation of your stake will also go up. Is that not the case?P Balasubramanian:ENI'snewsthat has come is on the Area-4 block. We are in Area-1. Definitely any new price discovery happening in those places will have an impact or will have addition, accretion to our assets value which has been kept very low because of the low oil prices. But it is too early days and nobody has confirmed the news yet.ET Now: What would you say is the total enterprise value of your global business? I know you have got very rich blocks and some of the blocks will start yielding returns in the next two or three years. So if you have to peg a value to your global business, what is the internal number?P Balasubramanian:I do not want to put a number. The Mozambique numbers are known. As we have got the news, Brazil is concerned. They are in the appraisal stage at this point in time. The reserves in place as well as the recoverable reserves of such blocks will be known only by late this year or early next year because appraisal programme has to be done based upon which we have to submit the necessary data to the government of Brazil for the developmental plans. So I am not able to assign a number at this point in time.ET Now: Your investment in global E&P; activity, will that be considered just as an investment where you have invested at the right time? If you get a good buyer, would you like to monetise on your assets or are you eventually in the long term interested in being an operator and running those assets?P Balasubramanian: From the beginning when we entered the upstream side, we have always been an active non-operator. That is the role that we have taken, by which I mean we have our own internal teams which apprise as such, which can discuss with other operators how the development plans and the exploration plans can be devised. So we are very active in this scheme though we are not operators in most of the blocks.Having said that, we are operators in two of the blocks in India, one as a joint operator in the Rajasthan Basin and another in the Cambay Basin where we are the operators. So we have our aspirations to become operators in the long run. But however, our entry to upstream is sort of a risk mitigation and partially to have some sort of control on oil as that is where our investments are.So we are long-term players as far as the upstream is concerned. We do not have any plans to hive off any assets at this point in time but upstream is a business where we have to see that once you have a sizableportfolioof assets, we have to see how to shuffle and reshuffle it but that is still a long way because we are yet to have any income earning assets in our books as of date."]

Author: ['ByAshutosh R Shyam, ET Bureau']
Title: ['If Exxon-ENI deal goes through, BPCL may get a stock re-rating']
Content: ["ETINTELLIGENCE GROUP: Falling energy prices and an inordinate delay in commissioning of i t s Mozambique gas field has pushed down the fair value of the overseas gas assets of Bharat Petroleum (BPCL) to low double digits. However, BPCL's overseas assets may get a shot in the arm ifExxonMobilacquires 25% stake in the Mozambique field from ENI, an Italian hydrocarbon major, for an estimated $3 billion. If this deal goes through, it will set a new valuation benchmark for the Mozambique assets in a low energy priceenvironment.The Mozambique field has two areas. Area 1 is the field in which BPCL holds 10%, operator for which is Anadarko, and Area 4 is operated by ENI.Analysts have been valuing the Mozambique gas asset stake of BPCL in the range of $5-11 billion, but based on ExxonMobil's offer for a 25% stake in Area 4, the implied value (of Areas 1 & 4) is estimated at $24 billion. This leaves enough room for an upward revision of the stock for the value of BPCL's gas assets.The BPCL's stake was valued in the range of Rs 35-65 per share by the analysts before the ExxonMobil's stake purchase plans. This is likely to go up Rs 200-225 per share based on the new valuation benchmark.At current price, however, the stock valuation does not appear to be at par with this stake. In addition, if crude continues to move up, it will further support BPCL's gas asset valuation, as most of the gas contracts are linked to crude oil prices.If Exxon buys up to 25% stake in ENI, it will try to find a way to buy into the field in which BPCL holds a stake, said a note by Citi. It may seek to synergise across the whole resource base, and this could likely result in a simplified operating structure."]

Author: ['PTI']
Title: ['IOC, BPCL clinch deal with RIL, Essar to restart diesel buy']
Tags: ['essar', 'RIL', 'Indian Oil Corp', 'Bharat Petroleum Corp', 'Hindustan Petroleum Corp']
Subtitle: ['During 2015-16, the three state-owned firms had bought over 12 mt of diesel and 0.6 mt of petrol from RIL and Essar.']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: State-owned IOC, BPCL and HPCL have struck a temporary deal with Reliance Industries andEssarOil to resume buying petrol and diesel from private refiners on revised terms.Short of own production, state refinersIndian Oil Corp(IOC),Hindustan Petroleum Corp(HPCL) andBharat Petroleum Corp(BPCL) buy about 12 million tonnes of diesel annually from Jamnagar refineries ofRILand the Vadinar unit of Essar.The arrangement, however, broke down earlier this year, with the private refiners seeking a better deal.Sources said private refiners previously paid central sales tax as well as coastal freight for shipping the fuel from their plants in Gujarat to consumption points in southern and eastern India.They wanted this cost to be borne by the buyers- IOC, BPCL and HPCL.As negotiations to work out a final arrangement continued, they resorted to imports as paying both central sales tax and freight would have made the fuel expensive.Now, an ad-hoc deal has been reached wherein the private refiners will pay the central sales tax and state-run marketing firms will bear the cost of coastal shipping.According to the sources, the state-owned firms are buying diesel from the two private refiners on a month-on-month basis.For example, for July, they would indicate the tentative requirement by June 10 and a firm number by June 24.A final deal is in the works and may take a few weeks to conclude, they added.During April-May, the three oil marketing companies have bought about 1.2 million tonnes of diesel from RIL and Essar. They also bought a small quantity of petrol (about 0.15 million tonnes).During 2015-16, the three state-owned firms had bought over 12 mt of diesel and 0.6 mt of petrol from RIL and Essar.Of this, IOC bought 1.86 mt of diesel and 1,37,000 tonnes of petrol.During April, India imported 0.5 mt of diesel, mostly on account of state-run oil firms not buying the fuel from RIL and Essar. Import during April 2015 was only 10,000 tonnes.The sources said state-owned oil firms need diesel from RIL and Essar as domestic consumption is rising at 7.6 per cent, its fastest pace in four years.']

Author: ['PTI']
Title: ['Core sector reform: BPCL allowed to raise foreign holding to up to 49%']

Author: ['ByAshutosh Shyam, ET Bureau']
Title: ['BPCL rides high on superior returns, earnings prospects']
Content: ["ET Intelligence Group: State-owned oil marketing companies often witnesses huge fluctuation in their operating profit, owing to their inventory losses that turn their earnings visibility hazy and shrink their price multiples. But,Bharat Petroleum Corporation(BPCL) has been able to avert these issues through efficient cost management.As a result, the country's second largest oil marketing company has improved the core return on equity (RoE), which excludes the impact of under recoveries on petroleum products, compared with peers. In FY12, BPCL's core RoE matched that of its peersIndian Oil(IOC), andHindustan Petroleum Corporation(HPCL). In FY16, it was 40% higher than the industry average. In the past two fiscal years, the company's core RoE was 25.3% and 28.8%, respectively.BPCL's refining profits have increased by four times in the past four fiscal years. The proportion of profit from refining in the total operating profit rose to 60% from 50%, during the period.The company's gross refining margin (GRM) improved as freight cost reduced by single point mooring (SPM) at Kochi refinery and higher distillate yield ? proportion ofcrude oilthat is converted into fuel. In addition, BPCL has refineries located near coastal areas ? at Mumbai and Kochi ? with installed refining capacity of 9.5 million metric tonnes (MMT) and 12 MMT, respectively. This reduces the need to hold higher inventory of crude oil. Companies such as IOC, which have inland refineries are required to invest in raw material inventories, which increases working capital requirement.The Kochi refinery capacity will be ramped up to 15.5 MMT by September 2016. Due to this, GRM is expected to increase by $1.5-2 per barrel by the end of the fiscal. Every $1/bbl increase in GRM lifts the earnings growth by 12.5% for BPCL. The incremental earnings from expanded capacity will be an important factor this fiscal and next. This will offset wariness among the investors who believe earnings growth has peaked in FY16.On the marketing front, BPCL's throughput per outlet is 15% higher than peers. As a result, its sensitivity to subsidy burden and fluctuating marketing margin is lower. According to analysts, every Rs0.1/litre increase in the marketing margin will improve earnings per share of FY17 by 3.4%. AtCMPof Rs1,024, BPCL is valued at 9x FY18 earnings, which appears inexpensive in light of superior return ratio, valuation of itsMozambiqueasset and earnings growth."]

Title: ['D Rajkumar appointed CMD of BPCL; Utpal Bora to head Oil India']

Content: ["NEW DELHI: TechnocratsD RajkumarandUtpal Borawere today appointed asChairman and Managing Director(CMD) ofBharat Petroleum Corporation Ltd(BPCL) andOil India Ltd, respectively.Rajkumar is, at present, working as Managing Director of BharatPetro Resources Ltd, a unit of BPCL focused on exploration and production. Author: ['ByPratik Bhakta, ET Bureau']
Title: ['BPCL picks up 21 per cent stake in Fino PayTech for Rs 250 crore']
Content: ['MUMBAI:Bharat Petroleum Corporation (BPCL) has invested Rs 251 crore in Mumbai based payments companyFino PayTechto pick up 21% stake through an all cash deal. With this deal,Finowhich had been awarded the Payments Bank licence is within striking distance of reducing its foreign shareholding to less than 50% as mandated by theReserve Bank of India."BPCL intends to leverage thedistributionnetwork of Fino coupled with the ultimate launch of the Payments Bank that offers an excellent platform for providing customised payment offerings to its customers to drive its fuel and non fuelbusiness," said BPCL in a note to theBombayStock Exchange on Friday.Petroleum retailing company BPCL which has a huge customer base who uses its petrol pumps and LPG services intends to utilize this partnership with Fino for a complete payments solution which could help it increase customer loyalty and also make payments simpler."We believe more than 1 crorepeopleuse BPCL petrol pumps, around 4 crore people get LPGsubsidy, BPCL will use our payments solutions to offer easy payments options to its customers and through loyalty programmes in association with us can increase customer stickiness," said Rishi Gupta, CEO, FinoPayTech.Further Gupta added that with the fresh funds the company was planning to invest more intechnologyand developing the payments infrastructure to be able to support the customer needs of a public sector giant like BPCL.Fino PayTech which was incubated by ICICI Bank as a payments technology company way back in 2006 counts BlackStone, Intel Capital, ICICI, International Finance Corporation among its investors. However in order to be able to start its banking activities it needed to reduce its foreign shareholding to less than 50% from more than 70% as per instructions from the RBI."We are already in talks with few other investors to reduce the foreign shareholding further by another 5 to 10% to meet regulatory norms which should enable us to start our Payments Bank business within the next 6 months," said Gupta.Fino manages around 400retailpoints for remittances and bill payments across the country and has around 8000 agents doing enrolments under Jan Dhan Yojana. The company handles around Rs 7000 to 8000 crore in cash annually.Profitable since 2010, for the year 2014-15 Fino reported a gross revenue of Rs 219 crore and net profit of Rs 10 crore. The latest round of investment puts the valuation of the company at almost Rs 1000 crore.']

Author: ['ET Now']
Title: ['FINO to help us set up e platform for financial inclusion of rural areas: P Balasubramanian, BPCL']
Content: ['In a chat withET Now,PBalasubramanian, Director Finance, BPCL, says looking at leveragingBPCLnetwork as well as that of FINO to have overall financial inclusion and other allied services. Edited excerptsETNow: BPCL has bought 21 per cent stake in FINO PayTechfor Rs 250 crore. Interesting transaction, what may be the rationale behind this?P Balasubramanian:BPCL has got ambitious plans on usingtechnologyin the various segments of theretailmarket, especially urban, rural, highways and the semi urban areas. One of the things we are looking at is the electronic platform by which we can give the financial services for the overall financial inclusion of the rural areas, be it a money transfer service, be it cash withdrawal, domestic money transfer and proposition for enabled e-commerce etc for the rural.We would like to leverage our retail as well as LPG network to get into this market. We are also looking at two-wheeler, three-wheeler services apart from the electronic services in the ruralmarketand allied services likeDTHrecharge with any of the DTL companies as well as mobile rechargesothat thepeoplehave flexibility of time in doing these businesses apart from looking at the banking.ET Now: But a 250 crore investment for a 21 per cent stake, that is not going to move the needle for BPCL. Imeansome would argue that this is just a side investment. It looks great but will this move the needle for you?P Balasubramanian:We are looking at a strategic partnership with FINO and along with that we have taken an equity in FINO Pay Tech. The question is-- how to leverage the strength of mutual strength of each of the entities which FINO has got a big network of franchisees as well as their agencies through which they operate the other financial inclusion products. We are looking at leveraging our network as well as leveraging the network of FINO to have the overall financial inclusion and other allied services which will be the differentiator in the market orproductdifferentiation in this particular industry.So the service will be the key in this industry when the competition sets in. That is why we are looking a sort of a strategic alliance and investments in this regard.']

Author: ['ByAshutosh Shyam, ET Bureau']
Title: ['Axis,Yes, BPCL and Eicher may gain weight in MSCI India rejig']
Content: ["ET Intelligence Group: The weights of stocks such asAxis Bank,Yes Bank,BPCLandEicher Motorsis likely to increase in the range of 0.2-2.9% during the upcoming tweaking of the MSCI India index, a widely tracked emerging market index by global funds. Besides, traders may also evince interest in Bajaj Finserve andPidiliteas they are likely to be the new entrants in the index.On the other hand, the weight of DrReddy's Laboratories is likely to fall due to the buyback which will increase its promoters' holding. The quarterly tweaking of the MSCI India index will be announced on August 11 and will be effective from September 1.The MSCI stock selection is based on factors such as average traded volumes, free float market capitalisation and foreign portfolio investors (FPI) limit.According to Neeraj Agarwal, vice president at IDFC, there is a higher probability that weights of stocks such as Axis Bank, Yes Bank and Eicher Motors may be increased due to a rise in their free float shares ? shares which are available for trading other than those held by promoters. MSCI considers May 31 as the last date to compute quarterly rejig in August.However, there are a few exceptions for considering a free float changes done after the cut-off date. In the previous index rejig, weights of Maruti and Ashok Leyland were raised even when their FPI limits were increased after the cut-off date. If MSCI continues to consider the changes in FPI limit done after the cut-off date this time too, then Axis Bank, Yes Bank and BPCL will likely be accorded with a higher weightage.Axis Bank has a weight of 1.5% in the MSCI India. It increased the FPI limit twice. First, from 49% to 62% before May 31, and then to 74% on July 15. If MSCI considers May 31 as the cut-off date, Axis will have a new weight of 3.6%, but if computed on the basis of 74% FPI limit, the new weight will be 4.4%.An inclusion in the MSCI India leads to fund deployment by several passive funds in proportion to the weight assigned to the stock. A stock typically gains over the short-term if the average daily volume of the stock included in the index is lower versus the total demand by the passive funds. Foreign ETFs, whose portfolio mirrors the weight accorded by the MSCI, have invested nearly 10% of the total AUM in Indian equities."]

Author: ['ET Bureau']
Title: ['BPCL says gas production from Mozambique not before FY21']
Tags: ['Gas', 'BPCL', 'Mozambique', 'Bharat Petroleum Corporation Ltd', 'ONGC', 'Natural gas', 'Bharat Petroleum Corporation']
Content: ['MUMBAI: State-run oil marketing companyBharat Petroleum Corporation(BPCL) anticipates a two-year delay in startinggasproduction from Mozambique?s Rovuma basin where the company along with its consortium partners are working on revising investment plans in response to a fall in gas prices.BPCL?s upstream arm, Bharat PetroResources, reckons that the first gas would not be produced before 2020-21, as against the earlier schedule of 2019. The company, which owns 10% in the asset which at the time of its discovery in 2010 was the largest in theworld, is part of the consortium that was planning to invest a total of $21 billion in the project.?The capex plan is undergoing revision. Legal compliance and framework is very important for us at this point before there is a final investment agreement on the field. We are hopeful that sometime early next year we would finalise our investment decision,? said chairman and managing director S Varadarajan, late Wednesday.He said that the project would be financed in a debt-to-equity ratio of 60:40.BPCL has chalked out an investment plan of Rs 100,000 crore for the next five years across operations, of which Rs 20,000 crore would be on upstream projects. Crude oil prices have plummeted by over half in the past two years, forcing energy majors across the world to slash their capex. There is an oversupply of rigs and exploration services have seen a decline in prices by almost 30%.A senior BPCL executive said that all stakeholders are working out a new investment plan but they are yet to reach a consensus on how much reduction should be done in investment to factor in the fall in project cost and the current gas prices. Besides BPCL, other members of the consortium are -- Anadarko (26.5%), also the operator of the block;ONGCVidesh (10%), Beas Rovuma EnergyMozambique(10%), PTTEP (8.5%) and Mitsui E&P; Mozambique (20%). The Mozambique government-owned Empresa Nacional de Hidrocarbonetos E.P holds 15%.']

Author: ['PTI']
Title: ['BPCL Kochi Refinery set to become world-class: Dharmendra Pradhan']
Subtitle: ['The minister said about Rs 30,000 crore worth of investment is being implemented in Kerala including that of enhancing crude refining capacity of Kochi Refinery and the petrochemical complex.']
Content: ['KOCHI: BPCLKochi Refineryis all set to become a world-class refiner withcrude oilprocessing capacity of 15.5 MMTPA, Union MinisterDharmendraPradhan said today."The Kochi Refinery had embarked on a great journey by processing 2.5 Million Metric Tonnes Per Annum (MMTPA) and presently is in the threshold of becoming a world-class refinery with crude oil refining capacity of 15.5 MMTPA," the Oil and Petroleum Minister said.Pradhan was speaking at a function to commemorateBPCLKochi Refinery\'s Golden Jubilee here.The refinery is also setting up a petrochemical complex which would enhance thevalue chain, generate employment opportunities and increase economic activity in Kerala, he said.BPCL will set up a green bio-fuel refinery to produce ethanol at Kochi by converting agricultural and municipal waste, he added.The minister said about Rs 30,000 crore worth of investment is being implemented in Kerala including that of enhancing crude refining capacity of Kochi Refinery and the petrochemical complex.Rajya Sabha Deputy Chairman P J Kurian and State Power Minister Kadakampally Surendran were among those present on the occasion.Meanwhile, a press release said Kochi Refinery is undertaking the implementation of its Integrated Refinery Expansion Project (IREP) which is in its final stages.On other activities, release said BPCL in collaboration with other oil companies and the state government is setting up a world-class skill development institute at Ettumanoor near Kottayam.A framework agreement to this effect has been signed with the state government and select courses will be started in November 2016.Nettur Technical Training Foundation(NTTF) has been identified as the training partner for conducting the skill development training programme.']

Author: ['ByJoel Rebello, ET Bureau']
Title: ['BPCL could raise $1 billion next week']
Content: ["MOil marketing companyBharat PetroleumCorp Ltd (BPCL) could raise anything between $500 million to $1 billion by selling dollarbondsto investors abroad as early as next week, in the first such exercise by an Indian company in 2017, three people familiar with the deal said.The money will be used to refinance short term loans taken by the company to buy stakes in Tass-Yuryakh and Vankor, two oil fields operated by Russian government owned oil giantRosneft, one of these people said.Last year BPCL along withIndian OilCorp Ltd andOil Indiahad jointly bought 29.9% stake in Taas-Yuryakh oilfield in East Siberia for $1.12 billion and 23.9% in the Vankor oilfield for $2.02 billion. The three companies had jointly taken a $2 billion short term loan for the same.The bonds will be sold through the company?s Singapore based subsidiary BPRL International Singapore Pte Ltd and will be of a five year tenure. Five banks, namely Citibank NA, Standard Chartered Plc, DBS Ltd, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group andSBICapital Markets are helping BPCL raise the money, these people said.Bankers will organise investor meets for the bond buyers in Hong Kong, Singapore and London starting on Thursday and continuing early next week these people said.Earlier on Wednesday, Fitch Ratings assigned a 'BBB-(EXP)' to the bonds in line with the $2 billion medium term note program of BPCL. ?BPCL will unconditionally and irrevocably guarantee up to 120% of the total aggregate principal amount of the proposed senior unsecured notes. The notes will rank pari passu with other senior unsecured borrowings of BPCL,? Fitch said.BPCL draws its rating from the Government of India (GoI)?s BBB- which is a majority shareholder with 54.9% stake. ?Fitch believes the linkages remain strong despite the deregulation of diesel prices in 2014 and introduction of the direct benefit transfer scheme - which transfers subsidies directly to the consumers - for household liquefied petroleum gas (LPG),? the rating agency said.Fitch said it will reassess BPCL's linkages with the state if the state-owned oil marketing companies' policy role weakens due to further deregulation of prices for petroleum products. It will also take into consideration the government's commitment to maintaining market-based prices for already deregulated products when oil prices rise. On a standalone basis Fitch rates BPCL?s credit profile at 'BB+'."]

Author: ['ByNayantara Rai, ET Now']
Title: ['Govt tells IOC, HPCL, BPCL to double dividend payout']
Content: ['Double thedividendpayout to Rs 15,000-16,000 crore. That\'s what the Centre -- and the largest shareholder of the state-owned oil marketing companies -- is demanding fromIOC,BPCLandHPCL. Last fiscal, these three cash rich oil PSUs cumulatively paid Rs 8,119 crore in dividend to all shareholders, and also as dividenddistributiontax to the government.Sources say this demand for the higher dividends from the finance ministry has been communicated to the oil companies via the petroleum ministry.The Centre is seeking a higher dividend on the back of IOC, HPCL and BPCL reporting much higher profits in the first half of this fiscal, as well as improved earnings per share.The demand from the oil PSUs exceeds the minimum dividend payout criterion. Last year, theNarendra Modigovernment had mandated every state-run firm to pay a minimum dividend of 30 per cent of its net profit or 5 per cent ofnet worth, whichever is higher and subject to the maximum dividend permitted under the law.Higher dividends from cash-rich public sector undertakings will provide the exchequer a fiscal cushion to push the economy.Sources add the Centre may make similar demands from other cash-rich PSUs. "The onus is on the government to kick start the economy considering the private sector has failed to increase its spending. There is no sense in the cash rich PSUs to sit on their cash," said a senior official in the finance ministry.OMCs Improved profitability:CompanyH1 FY17H1FY16ProfitabilityIOCRs 11,391 crRs 6141 cr85 per centHPCLRs 2800 crRs 1287 cr116 per centBPCLRs 3925 crRs 3395 cr16 per cent']

Subtitle: ['The official said the fire occurred at the substation during temporary maintenance work at 10 AM today.\n\n[Representative image]']
Content: ['KOCHI: Two contract workers were injured in a "minor fire incident" at the substation of a captive power plant inBharat Petroleum Corporation Limited\'sKochi Refinery Complexnear here today.The plant was shut briefly after the workers were injured in the "localised electric fire" at the substation of a captive power plant in the refinery complex, aBPCLofficial said.Fire fighters were immediately pressed into service to doused the fire, he said.The official said the fire occurred at the substation during temporary maintenance work at 10 AM today.Two persons, identified as Velayudhan (53) and Arun (30), were injured and were admitted to the burns ICU unit of a private hospital in Kochi, he said.Officials said both Velayudhan and Arun are contract workers employed at the plant.Police said one of the workers had suffered serious burn injuries.']

Author: ['ByJoel Rebello,Saikat Das,Mohit Bhalla, ET Bureau']
Title: ['BPCL raises $600 million through bond sale; NTPC plans to take same route soon']
Tags: ['BPCL', 'indian oil', 'State Bank Of India', 'SBI', 'NTPC', 'Oil India', 'Bharat Petroleum']
Subtitle: ['This bond will open the door for more Indian companies to raise money.', '']
Content: ['NEW DELHI | MUMBAI: Overseas fund raising season kicked-off for the year with state-ownedBharat PetroleumCorp mopping up funds at a cheaper rate andNTPCplanning similar bond sale within weeks.Oil marketing companyBPCLon Wednesday raised $600 million by selling 10-year dollar bonds to investors in Asia and Europe.BPCL\'s Singapore arm BPRL International Singapore Pte Ltd raised the money at 200 basis points above the 10-year US treasury which came to around 4.375per cent. "The bond was raised at a rate which is among the best in 10 years. This bond will open the door for more Indian companies to raise money," said a banker involved in the deal.Investors bid for $1.7 billion of the issue out of which the company retained $600 million. About three-fourth of the investors were from Asia while the remaining were from the Middle East and Europe. BPCL will use the money to refinance short term loans taken by the company to buy stakes in Tass-Yuryakh and Vankor, two oil fields operated by Russian government owned oil giant Rosneft. Five banks, namely Citibank NA, Standard Chartered Plc, DBS Ltd, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group andSBICapital Markets helped the company to sell bonds.NTPC plans to sell foreign currency denominated bonds worth at least 500 million euros within the next two weeks, said people familiar with the proposed issue. The state-owned utility will conduct road shows in Europe starting Monday.The bonds will be offered as part of a programme to borrow $4 billion to meet funding requirements.NTPC, the country?s power generation company, is expected to spend as much as $8 billion on capital expenditure over the next two years as it gears up to bid for ultra-mega power plants ? of 4 gigawatts (GW) capacity each ? when they are offered, and also attempts to acquire state-owned thermal power plants.The company is said to have mandated Barclays, Citigroup, Standard Chartered, Axis Bank and Bank of Tokyo Mitsubishi UFJ to arrange the bond sale. ?The company plans to diversify its borrowing resources globally while rising US Treasury yields have made borrowing a bit expensive for Indian borrowers in the US?, a person familiar with the company?s thinking said.Ratings agency Fitch assigned a BBB-(expected) rating on the proposed issue of notes by the company on Wednesday citing NTPC?s ?dominant market position? as one of the key rating drivers.']

Tags: ['Bharat Petroleum', 'bonds', 'BPCL', 'NATIONAL STOCK EXCHANGE', 'Debentures', 'Bharat Petroleum Corp Ltd', 'of India Ltd']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: State-ownedBharat Petroleum Corp Ltdtoday said it will raise Rs 2,000 crore in debt in the current fiscal ending March 31 to fund its capex requirements.In a notice to stock exchanges,BPCLsaid its shareholders had on September 21 last year approved raising of funds through \'Private Placement of Non-Convertible Bonds/Debentures and/orOther Debt Securities\'."In exercise of the said delegated authority, BPCL is planning to raise up to Rs 2,000 crores during the current financial year through private placement of secured non- convertibledebenturessubject to market conditions," it said.The debentures are proposed to be listed on Debt Market segment of the BSE Ltd and National Stock Exchangeof India Ltd(NSE).Last month, BPCL had raised USD 600 million by selling 10-year dollarbondsto investors in Asia and Europe.Its Singapore armBPRL International Singapore Pte Ltdraised the money at 200 basis points above the 10-year US treasury which came to around 4.375 per cent.BPCL had at that time stated that it will use the money to refinance short term loans taken by the company to buy stakes in Tass-Yuryakh and Vankor, two oil fields operated by Russian government owned oil giant Rosneft.']

Author: ['ByAman Sharma, ET Bureau']
Title: ["Government's plan to create an integrated oil company may see ONGC taking over HPCL or BPCL"]
Subtitle: ['"The plan is to transfer the government??s holding to ONGC, which will become the holding firm of one of these cos," sources said.']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: The government??s plan to create an integrated oil company will likely involve Oil and Natural Gas Corp taking over either Hindustan Petroleum Corp (HPCL) or Bharat Petroleum Corp (BPCL) but won??t result in a mega merger leading to the creation of an industry giant.In his February 1 Budget speech, FM Arun Jaitley had said the government proposes to ??create an integrated public sector oil major which will be able to match the performance of international and domestic private sector oil and gas companies??.The merged entity will span the spectrum of activity from exploration to retail sale, said officials who elaborated on the strategy on condition of anonymity. ??The actual intention behind the Budget announcement is not to create one huge oil firm,?? one of them said. Under the plan, explorerONGCwill ??control?? HPCL or BPCL, which are refining and distribution companies.??Currently, HPCL and BPCL have the government as the majority shareholder. The plan is to transfer the government??s holding to ONGC, which will become the holding firm of one of these companies (HPCL or BPCL),?? said a person cited above.The government does not intend to tinker around with any of the other upstream companies such as Oil India Ltd (OIL) or downstream ones like Indian Oil Corporation Ltd (IOC).??Hence, this proposal does not result in any reduction in competition or efficiency in the oil sector,?? said one of the persons cited above. One of the key ideas behind the plan is to lower risk, he said.??The world over, the largest and most successful oil companies like Shell, BP and Exxon are vertically integrated,?? the person said. ??They combine exploration activities with refining and distribution.??The logic is that when crude oil prices are high, the exploration business does well and when they drop, the distribution business benefits, said the people cited above.??By combining the two in a single company, the overall profit of the undertaking becomes more stable. Investors benefit from reduced volatility of profits,?? said another official. In order to achieve the objective, the government plans to transfer its majority shareholding in HPCL or BPCL to ONGC, said the people cited above.These sources said a ??complete merger?? of the two entities may take longer and the basic objective of integration can be achieved even without this.The Budget announcement had led to intense speculation that the government intended a grand merger of all the oil companies to create one mammoth entity. Critics had flagged the various problems that could result from such a merger.State-owned ONGC is the country??s biggest oil producer and one of the largest companies in the country.HPCL, a Navratna company, owns and operates two major refineries in Mumbai of 6.5 million metric tonnes per annum (MMTPA) capacity and another in Visakhapatnam of 8.3 MMTPA capacity besides owning and operating the largest lube refinery in the country. IOC is the nation??s largest refiner and fuel retailer.']

Title: ['Bonanza for shareholders: Oil marketing cos IOC, HPCL, BPCL declare dividends']
Subtitle: ['On BSE, 4.99 lakh shares of HPCL were traded on the counter. As many as 1.99 lakh shares of IOC have exchanged hands on the exchange.']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: Shares of oil marketing companies Hindustan Petroleum Corporation (HPCL) andIndian Oil Corporation(IOC) hogged the limelight in afternoon trade on Thursday after these firms announced interimdividendfor the financial year 2016-17.HPCL declared an interim dividend of Rs 6.40 per equity share of face of Rs 10 each for the financial year 2016-17. The board has fixed March 27 as therecord dateto determine the eligibility of the shareholder to receive the said second interim dividend. The dividend is proposed to be paid on or before March 31, 2017.Shares of HPCL were trading 2.06 per cent higher at Rs 521.50 after the announcement of dividend around 1.40 pm (IST). The scrip opened at Rs 520 and touched a high and low of Rs 527 and Rs 518.85, respectively, in trade so far.Moreover, Indian Oil Corporation declared an interim dividend of Rs 4.50 per share for FY17. The board of IOC has fixed March 27 as the record date. Shares of the company were trading 1.13 per cent up at Rs 376.65 in the afternoon trade.On BSE, 4.99 lakh shares of HPCL were traded on the counter so far as against the average daily volumes of 1.87 lakh shares in the past two weeks. On the other hand, 1.99 lakh shares of IOC have exchanged hands on the exchange as against the average daily volumes of 1.76 lakh shares in the past two weeks.Shares of HPCL hit their fresh 52-week high of Rs 584.45 on February 14, 2017 and 52-week low of Rs 246.50 on March 28. IOC hit fresh 52-week high of Rs 403.95 on February 7, 2017 and 52-week low of Rs 195.43 on March 23, 2016.Another oil marketing company BPCL also declared an interim dividend for the ongoing financial year on Thursday.??The Board of Directors have declared second special interim dividend of Rs 12 per equity share of face value Rs 10/- each i.e. 120 per cent on the paid-up equity share capital of the Company for the Financial Year 2016-17,?? the company said in a regulatory filing.??Further, the Board of Directors have fixed Monday, 27th March, 2017 as record date to determine the eligibility of the shareholders to receive the said 2nd Special Interim Dividend,?? it added.These developments come a day after when another commodity firm, Hindustan Zinc, declared a special one-time interim dividend of 1,375 per cent i.e. R. 27.50. This would entail an outflow of Rs 13,985 crore including dividend distribution tax (DDT). The record date for the dividend will be March 30, 2017.']

Author: ['ETMarkets.com']
Title: ['IOC, BPCL, HPCL mixed as petrol prices to change every day from May 1']
Content: ['Shares of oil marketing companies (OMCs) ended mixed after companies said that come May 1, petrol and diesel prices will change every day in sync with international rates, much like what happens in most advanced markets.Bharat Petroleum Corporation (BPCL) and Hindustan Petroleum Corporation (HPCL) ended higher by 1 per cent and 0.65 per cent, respectively, but Indian Oil corporation ended lower by 0.32 per cent.These three oil marketing companies owns over 95 per cent of nearly 58,000 petrol pumps in the country. IOC, BPCL and HPCL will launch a pilot for daily price revision in five select cities from May 1 and gradually extend it to all over the country.At present, OMCs revise rates on 1st and 16th of every month based on average international price of the fuel in the preceding fortnight and currency exchange rate.Instead of using fortnightly average, pump rates will reflect daily movement in international oil prices and rupee- US dollar fluctuations.For the quarter ended December 31, 2016, BPCL reported 47.04 per cent year-on-year rise in net profit at Rs 2,271.94 crore. HPCL and IOC posted 52.73 per cent and 29.04 per cent YoY increase in bottomline figures at Rs 1,590.31 crore and Rs 3,994.91 crore during the quarter under review.']

Author: ['PTI']
Title: ["Insulated pipeline to boost BPCL Kochi Refinery's capacity"]
Subtitle: ['The project has helped Kochi Refinery to enhance its capacity to 15.5 MMTPA and produce eco-friendly products complying to BS-IV norms.']
Content: ["KOCHI: With an objective to enhance the value chain of petroleum products, Bharat Petroleum Corporation Limited (BPCL) is replacing the old 30-inch crude pipeline with 20-inch insulated pipeline from South Tanker Berth Jetty toKochi Refinery.The Public Sector Undertaking under the Ministry of Petroleum & Natural Gas said the new pipeline would help Kochi Refinery to transport high viscous petroleum products like vacuum residue (HSVR) and vacuum gas oil (VGO) from other refineries in the country and process these products into value-added products ofdieselandpetrol.Since most of the other Indian refineries don't have the bottom upgradation capabilities, this business model would help the country produce additional value-added products, the company said in a release here.The release said the Kochi Corporation had given the nod for laying pipeline in areas under its jurisdiction. As part of the agreement, Kochi Refinery had contributed Rs.five crore for developmental activities in the Corporation.In this regard, a cheque for Rs.five crore was handed over to Kochi Mayor Soumini Jain by BPCL Kochi Refinery's Executive Director Prasad K Panicker yesterday in presence of Ernakulam MP K V Thomas, MLA Hibi Eden and other dignitaries.BPCL Kochi Refinery had attained the capability of processing high viscous petroleum products and indigenous crudes with the implementation of its Rs.16,500 crore Integrated Refinery Expansion Project (IREP).The project has helped Kochi Refinery to enhance its capacity to 15.5 MMTPA and produce eco-friendly products complying to BS-IV norms.Now that IREP is commissioned, Kochi Refinery is one of the few in India capable of processing heavy high viscous crude oil from Barmer oil fields in Rajasthan, the release said.The pipeline will help Kochi Refinery in importing this high viscous indigenous crude oil at a much lower cost. Also, it would help increase the production of diesel.The pipeline will also help in importing diesel or petrol from other locations in case of product shortage due to shutdown of refinery unit for maintenance or any other reason as well as for export of surplus products generated when the plants are running in fully expanded capacity of 15.5 MMPTA, the company said."]

Author: ['ETMarkets.com']
Title: ['Sensex, Nifty50 start on a cautious note; BHEL, BPCL top losers']
Content: ['NEW DELHI: Benchmark indices opened on a poor note on Tuesday amid weakness in other Asianmarketsafter reports emerged that Greece may forgo its next bailout payment if creditors cannot strike a debt relief deal and Italy may go for an early election. US markets were closed overnight on account of Memorial Day and, back home, investors were bracing for a busyearningsday that was set to see reporting of March quarter results by over 1,350 firms.At 9.25 am, the BSESensexwas trading 3 points, or 0.01 per cent, higher at 31,112. The NSE?s barometerNifty50 fell 19 points, or 0.20 per cent, to 9,585.70. Midcap and Smallcap indices fell up to half-a-per cent.There were reports that the southwestmonsoonwould hit the Kerala coast and northeast India simultaneously on Tuesday, the onset date forecast by theIndia Meteorological Departmentearlier this month.Among Sensex stocks,Ciplarose 1.66 per cent to Rs 512.50.GAILadvanced 1.42 per cent to Rs 404.30 while pharma stocks Luipn andSun Pharmaadded 1.3 per cent each.Coal Indialed Sensex losers. The scrip fell 1.79 per cent to Rs 262.85. The state-owned company has reported 38 per cent decline in its consolidated net profit at Rs 2,716 crore for the March quarter.TCSandWiprofell 1.5 per cent and 0.9 epr cent, respectively.ITCwas down 0.79 per cent at 313.50.Anant Raj,Apollo Hospitals,Berger Paints,BEML, EIH,Gitanjali Gems, IRB Infra, Max Financial Services andNatco Pharmaare among 1,362 BSE-listed companies scheduled to report quarterly earnings on Tuesday. Overall, 2,390 firms have reported a 3.7 per cent YoY rise in net profit at Rs 91,213 crore on 12.32 per cent YoY jump in net sales at Rs 13,23,665 crore.']

Author: ['ET Now']
Title: ['It is very difficult to predict the crude trajectory: K Sivakumar, BPCL']
Content: ['In a chat withET Now, K Sivakumar, Director-Finance,BPCLsays, "we see the crude in the range of between 50-55 and definitely it is the geopolitical considerations will determine the price of crude." Edited excerpts:ET Now: Your GRM is at $6.1 per barrel came in much better than estimates, what is the outlook on GRMs going forward from here, do you think you will be able to better this performance in the next few quarters?K Sivakumar:Actually we have tracked the Singapore GRMs and then we are confident that the current trend will continue.ET Now: When you say the current trend will continue, will it be in the $6.1-$6.5 per barrel range or do you think you can better than significantly?K Sivakumar:It will be range bound. Because it depends on the crack spreads of the MS and HSD therefore it will be range bound.ET Now: Even your top line and bottom line this quarter was better than estimates, how was the quarter in terms of volumes on your various products that is diesel, petrol,LPGas well as kerosene?K Sivakumar:Actually for the year MS retail we have improved by 6.68%, LPG at 11.8 and ATF 20.64, for the year I mean, and there is a small drag in HSD to the extent of 1.78%.ET Now: How much was the throughput in the quarter versus last year?K Sivakumar:Throughput for the quarter was 6.02 MMT.ET Now: Tell us a little bit more about thecapexas well that you have lined for FY18 as compared to what you have already done previously?K Sivakumar:Actually, the integrated refinery expansion is behind us now and the commissioning process of major unit has been completed except the couple of units which will get done in the next couple of months. So we have the petrochemical projects which were the PDPP project so that will take off now. And there are certain other projects in theMumbai refineryand the marketing infrastructure, at Haldia a new terminal is also there so the capex plans will be as planned which we have done.ET Now: You must be tracking the crude movements as well pretty closely, lot is happening on the global political landscape as well which keeps on impacting crude prices, of late crude has gotten pretty volatile, what is your own sense on what trajectory are we likely to see from crude prices in the near to medium term?K Sivakumar:We see the crude in the range of between 50-55 and definitely it is the geopolitical considerations will determine the price of crude. It is very difficult to predict what will be the crude trajectory but we feel that it should be range bound between 50-55 is what we look at.']
